Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Void, I always felt like I understood that word. Looking back I realize I was naive, or maybe I was too full of hope. Me and Maria created the nano bots for constuction, as a way to ease the burden of building the lunar colony. She had survived the imperial invasion in the ruins of Los Angeles, she thought she could create a brighter future. Selfishness, that's what undid everything. Eventually the colonists decided they could n't abide the laws of earth. The people of earth decided they would n't abide rebels on the moon. They could n't accept those resources would be used for something other than their gain. So I reprogrammed the bots, I did n't tell her, how could I? They were meant to break things down and rebuild faults in the domes, I just allowed them to accept new targets. Of course she figured it out. With Maria gone I wanted to die, but I could n't. She dreamed of a world without conflict, where everyone had enough. I knew they would n't come willingly, so I lied. I told them I could make the bots fix the domes; that everything would be alright. Instead I joined my mind with them. At first I was in control. They tried to stop me, but the bots ate whatever they sent to harm me. I created massive pylon factories across the globe preparing for their acsension. I was lazy, a single mistake doomed everything. I set my neural pattern as the administrator. The others where sublimated within me. What else could I do, I had to quiet their voices or be driven mad. That was when the machines decided to best safeguard my well being they had to take over several key roles. What we needed most was matter, for fuel and to rebuild lost bots. We became a swarm. We devoured the earth in minutes. And so we drifted, eating always eating. We found the hive ships, sent centuries before my birth. We ate evrrything, and added the humans to the databanks. I saw nebulae beyond comprehension, their beauty cut down by their hunger. The only hope I had left was to leave beacons containing copies of my mind. Perhaps someone could find them, and destroy the swarm. We encountered aliens with fantastical technology, they attacked me with lasers that could cut through time itself. Still we fed. Stars were broken down bit by bit to fulfill our needs. Millenia passed and the feasts became further and further apart. With the lack of resources came concessions. More systems were shut down to survive. They cared only for me. It took Millenia but now only I remain the databanks purged. I remain as a single beacon, and a lone drone. It spends it's days savoring specs of matter it finds in the void. A true void of my own creation. I pray there is a god, and it can repair what I have sundered. I pray that this beacon survives and whoever manages to access it heads my warning. I know these prayers stem from desperation. At one time I spanned the entire universe. There is no God to save me. Calculations say I will subsist in this state for four thousand more years before the drone gives in, and deactivates. After that, I will shut down, eventually. I do not know how long that will take. I know that I will forget. I will forget the beauty I found and consumed. I will forget the humans that cried out in that terrible moment. I will forget her.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
It was about that time again. The dawn of a new day, when humans thought to sneak up on the Deep Woods Dragon while it slept. It feared the way the sun reflected off of it' s scales, they said. It' s prismatic hide was so bright it was blinding. If taunted into the sun, they said, the Deep Woods Dragon could be defeated by the least trained of knights. The Deep Woods Dragon needed to be blinded, they said, or it would burn its attackers to ashes with rainbow-hued flames. He knew these rumors because the butterflies had told him. They were drawn to the rainbow of greens, yellows, pinks and purples of his scales, like the flowers they coveted so much. They had told him this, too, but the Dragon did not mind. The butterflies were honest, as their lives were short and beautiful. Even still, they could fly unhindered among the humans, even admired by the small humans who chased them, laughing. They told him stories while they rested on his wingtips, tail, and snout. Butterflies did not fear the Dragon, because they knew the truth. With a yawn, the Dragon shifted its weight to better perch itself on the tree' s stout branch. This tree was taller than the others, and overlooked a small, circular clearing. Without the deer, the weeds thrived, covering the dirt in a green, tangled mass. At the edge of the clearing stood a massive cave entrance, vines draped over the sides of smooth rock. The Dragon had snapped off the vines in front of the entrance, to give the illusion of occupancy. This was, after all, where the humans thought he lived. He knew these rumors because the butterflies had told him. "In an ancient cave in the middle of the wood, lives an ancient dragon who' s up to no good!" That was what the small humans like to chant as they chased the butterflies and laughed. So the Dragon tore at the vines, and scared the graceful deer from the peaceful clearing. He had enjoyed watching the deer with their young as they grazed the clearing. From up above in his favorite tree, they could not see him, and they could not fear him. Three times a day, the Dragon glided down from his tree to the old cave' s opening. There, he took a deep breath and screamed as loud as he could. He cried in both low tones and high pitches. He wailed in imitation of female humans, shouted in a voice mimicking angry male humans. The Dragon stood on top of the cave and breathed eye-searing beams of light from his mouth to the sky. It scared the birds huddled in the trees, and the noises scared the deer far from the clearing. But they also scared the humans away from the Deep Woods. He knew these rumors because the butterflies had told him. So he made his noises, made the lights, and scared the humans away. Because any humans who saw the Dragon would discover the truth. Because, when the Dragon stepped into the sunlight, they' d see how small he really was. The Deep Woods Dragon, with prismatic scales that shone in the sun and such a frightening voice, was the size of a domestic house cat. And only the butterflies knew the truth.

God It's always difficult making tough decisions and this year I've made the hardest one of all, to eradicate sin and give humans another chance to embrace a new world. A world of peace, love and kindness where there will be no more tears. Of course in order for this to happen I have to prevent humans from actually doing sinful things, limiting their free will. Now I've debated this for eternity - literally - but to be honest, if I do n't step in the Nuclear war in 2018 would eradicate 99.9 % of the human race. I know what you're thinking, surely at that point I could step in and utilise that disaster as a fresh start. Although I see your point, i'm still experiencing the backlash about the flooding. So with that, on entering the year 2016, sin will leave the world. Every human will no longer be capable of sin. Satan Let's get something straight, I've always wanted the best for the human race. Think about it, back in the beginning with adam and eve, there was no sin, no free will to do anything you wanted. After I stepped in humanity had unlimited potential. Sure there's been war, famine, disease and death but there's been some remarkable things of human acheivement. I think you'll agree that God's plan to remove sin and thus freewill is a huge mistake. If anything he should go the opposite way, if he removed the linearity of time then nothing in the lives of humans would be predetermined. God Well a few hours in and already the world is changing for the better. For the first time, humanity all over the globe have united in wokring towards a better future. Money is no longer a concern and communities are aiding one another in anyway they can. Within the year the world should be unrecognisable, poverty and hunger no longer existing and humanity living in harmony with the earth. Satan So its only been a few hours and already I'm enjoying this more than anticipated, I did n't relise how unrewarding temptation was in the old world, people just caved so easily to their darkest desires. This new world, well this is a challenge. Even in Eden I had that tree of knowledge to play with. I've been working on quite a few things so far, sticking to the classics; wrath, greed, sloth, pride, lust, envy, and gluttony. All I need is one person to break, then its only a matter of time before the world one more begins its decent into chaos. This is going to be fun.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
I have reaped the souls of many over the course of my years as death. Souls of the good, the bad, and everything between have always been sown by another before I pluck them from the Earth at their appropriate time. Even the ones that believe it is n't their time or ask for just one more opportunity to do what they wish, must be taken without question because, well, its just the way my job is. To me, it never mattered where they were at in life. I just carried them over with ease. Never once had experienced trouble in my task as I had even had to pluck sweet children from the arms of their mothers. However, it all changed when I was tasked with taking the soul of David Mckiny. I watched David from the day he entered the Earth, and never before had I seen someone as special as him. He always thought of others first, always trying to help others before even contemplating his own commodities. I approached him on the fateful day at exactly noon. He was old now, no longer in his prime as he was finally about to lose his battle with cancer. I approached him as the hourglass emptied completely to the bottom. I spoke to him," David you must know who I am at this hour." He answered not necessarily speaking to me," If only I had helped more.... If only I could have have had more time! How dreadful to go when so many more need help!" At this moment I found it immensely hard to fulfill my task. I was not met with a man begging for more time only to waste it on fruitless trivialities. I was met with a man who wanted to bring grace to more people. He wished not to make his life better, but only cares to try to improve as many others as possible. I finally brought myself to say," David you have been a good man, but death is one thing which is inevitable, and not even I can grant time when someone is due. You must come along now with me." He allowed his soul to leave his body, a tear running down his face as he did. I extended my arm to him and he obliged. If there is one final peace to the journey is the experience of seeing one's life pass by as I guide them to the next step. I saw, as we walked, countless people who David had helped, most of which he had n't known and would never see again. Every part of me wished to guide him back to his body, but I knew I had a task to fulfill, and I knew I had to complete it. After a long while of walking down the path, we finally came to the gateway where David would continue without my guidance. I never know where the person will go once they enter, but I knew David would go to a place that would have the same passion in death as he did in life. I never had such a hard time seeing someone move on, and I sat a while thinking of how tragic it is for someone like David, genuinely the best kind of person, to be taken from such a cruel world when he one of the few people who deserved to stay. Anyways I found myself contemplating to long, and I moved on to reap the rest of the souls I had to fetch that day.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
"Ah man, it smells like death in here." That is the phrase that I have lived to regret ever since they fell foolishly from my mouth. I was essentially immortal before that moment in time. I was the best comedian in the world, and apparently better than anyone in the afterlife as well. It was the only reason the Grim Reaper decided not to take me. I could make him laugh, and in his line of work that was a rarity. I do n't even remember what it was that I had said when he showed up at my car accident. I can recall him bending down next to my overturned Honda civic and reaching in to pull me out. I made some off the wall comment and he froze, dead in his tracks. It was the weirdest laugh I had ever heard, but one I appreciated more than all of the others combined. He let me live, provided that every year on the anniversary of what should have been my death, I would tell him a joke that would make him cry with laughter. I was his own personal jester, and for that he rewarded me handsomely. And then on that fateful day, 121 years later, I muttered those stupid words that seized our contract and ripped it in two. Who knew Death would be so self conscious about his smell? And to make things worse, that was n't even the joke that I was going to tell him! The actual joke was a masterpiece, but he would n't give me the chance to tell it. I ran out of that room faster than I'd ever run before. And I've been running ever since. I think the reason that he has n't taken me yet is because of our long history together. That is n't to say that he's forgiven me. He seems to enjoy reminding me that he's near. Everyone I get close to dies without reason. I'll see a dog in the park that I think looks adorable and before I can pet it, it'll fall over dead. Roses crumble before I can enjoy their scent and food rots on my fork before I can bring it to my mouth. He's killing everything around me. I have discovered that Death is a jester of a different sort. I had provided him with a form of humor that he was n't used to, but he has since grown tired of it, and reverted to his old ways. Now, he once again deals in jokes of cruelty and irony. In a way, I am still fulfilling my part of our old deal. The Reaper still laughs, and he still laughs at me. Only now, the difference is I'm not laughing.

He decides to start his own architecture firm. His first project is a house for Peter Keating. Roark designs a house that is completely square. Keating reluctantly agrees to build the house, but he is sure that it will be a disaster. To his surprise, however, the house is a huge success. People love its simplicity and efficiency, and soon other architects are copying Roark's style. Roark becomes famous, and his firm grows rapidly. Soon, he is one of the most successful architects in the world.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
I looked up in horror at the crowd of young boys came thundering into the room. The clouds on the walls were suddenly blocked by a horde of scrambling young bodies and flailing limbs. I froze, the hat on my head tilted just enough for me to see everything, and i saw fear. Andy stood there in the middle of the floor, clutching the dreaded spaceman box, but that seemed to matter less compared to the pressing matter. The air was still, I could feel Mr.Potato head's round eyes blink and the sound of heavy breathing from the guests penetrated the silence with jagged blades of uncertainty. I considered freezing, but it was too late. We all knew it. Rex panicked like a child who came down christmas morning to find no gifts. He thundered across the hardwood floors for the window, yelling at the top of his lungs some inaudible dinosaur screech. I spun around, knowing it was too late and pointed towards the window. The toys did n't need a second prompt. The strong man and Mr. Potato head grabbed the monkeys in a barrel, hopped in RC and gunned the engines. The army men attempted to rescue some of the less mobile toys, but it was too late. One brilliant child had the idea to grab my waist with his sweaty, greasy hand and hold me up in the air. I put up a fight, hoping to distract them enough to let everyone escape. I did n't know what would happen, but panic had overrun my emotions and pure terror coursed through my plastic veins. But then, salvation. Andy wrenched me from the child's grasp and shouted angrily "YOU ONLY GOT ME BEDSHEETS." He held me gently in his grasp and managed to utter "Woody?" I stared back up at him with and sorrow filled my soul. I knew this was it, the other toys were out. "I'm sorry Andy, you'll understand one day." I flung my sack cloth limbs out of his hand and towards the bed, hitting it with surprising force. I propelled myself towards the window, clear through the slit. The other toys were already at the edge of the law waiting for me, but I had to look back at least once. Andy stared out the window with a look of pure despair on his face and one confused spaceman peered back, blinking quizzically towards the small group of toys, running down the street; never to return.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
We attack immediately at sundown, once their solar power cells are no longer generating power and they are instead using stored power. Forcing the enemy to rely on finite reserves is a good strategy. From our intel gathering and scouting missions we know the machines' first response will be to send two robots per every identified threat. Not a bad bit of logic on their part. The wolves were able to acquire video of some of the human assaults. We can confirm each localized machine hub will have, at minimum, 50000 robot responders. Luckily, we have some numbers. The machines decided not to bury the dead or finish off the wounded humans but to ship them away from the machine hubs. The wolf and bat armies grew after each human battle. Intel reports also bolstered our confidence that the robots would have diminished ability to fend off our armies. The machines graciously eliminated silver from any of their infrastructure, preferring either denser or more conductive metal depending on the situation. The machines also eliminated religion from their human cattle, ending the scourge of crosses or other offending accoutrements. Also, the machines removed unnecessary costs in generating food for their human cattle, including flavorings such as garlic. We've coordinated our attack with other armies across the world. Tonight's sunset heralds our initial assault, beginning in the pacific and escalating westward as the sun's influence retreats behind the horizon. We have factored in failure to our first battle. Armies will retreat north to arctic regions taking advantage of the extended nights. Getting our allies from the southern hemisphere to agree that we should retake the northern hemisphere first was hard, the logistics of getting them north of the equator to join our armies was doubly so. We've drawn up a general strategy for every localized unit to follow, leaving room for them to improvise should any unforeseen complications arise. At sunset, send 50000 foot soldiers to each hub. Once the robots stop pouring out of the hub we set off EMPs. The humans discovered this only gained them around 30 seconds of disorientation within the robots. Immediately following the EMPs we electrify the magnets we've buried in the ground. A functioning robot can not be immobilized by a magnet. A disoriented one, however will be more susceptible. After that we fight. A hopefully diminished robot army will now be fighting what they will perceive as humans an large dogs. That's where our superhuman strength, speed, agility, and healing capabilities will come into play. During the ground assault a smaller team is to sever all outside communications from each hub. Disrupted communications should at least slow down global coordination with other hubs. We wanted to take out their communications before each assault, however the machines' penchant for redundancy and underground infrastructure proved cumbersome. It was decided to utilize the distraction of our infantry attacks as the opportunity to get around access issues. Watching the seconds tick by waiting for our signal to move should be nothing compared to the centuries I've been hiding underground waiting to resurface. Sadly this is not the case. I'm comforted by thoughts of global supremacy should we succeed. I'm not looking forward to the inevitable Werewolf/Vampire war that will take place after our victory over the machines. We'll have to deal with that problem when it comes, I suppose. For right now it's time to transform into a wolf. I've got some metal to munch.

As the investigation progresses, Lisbeth discovers that there is much more going on than just a simple sex scandal. She uncovers evidence of corruption, blackmail, and even murder. With her hacking skills and investigative prowess, Lisbeth is able to piece together the truth and expose those responsible.

She must navigate a dangerous underworld of criminals and corrupt officials while trying to stay one step ahead of the authorities. Despite these difficulties, Lisbeth remains determined to see justice served and the truth revealed.

The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo is a thrilling and suspenseful novel that explores themes of corruption, power, and revenge.

The shrill whistle blew and everyone around me started to board the train, I walked in with them, shuffling my feet and quickly finding a seat not next to anyone. I take a quick scan of the train, watching the stream of grey individuals start to fill the empty spaces and I smile pleasantly as a man sits next to me. He smiles back, but a little uncertain, he takes another look at my direction and says "dude, why is your shirt bright, and I mean bright, pink". Looking down at my grey shirt I sigh, I asked the lady at the store where I bought it, if it looked nice on me and was n't too bright. I'm sure it wo n't be the last joke someone will play on me. Indulging the stranger I quickly explain that my life is devoid of colour and to me everything looks grey. He frowns at my answer, "are n't you really sad? it's depressing to have everything grey" "I do n't think so" I respond, "I've been this way my whole life, to me, it's normal. Hours pass and it's finally lunch time, I'm sitting in my usual cafe eating my usual sandwich when she walks in. My eye's are drawn to this beautiful women, she stands out from everyone, because she is not grey. I do n't know how to calm my mind, her dress is so bright it almost hurt's, her hair is darker then the dress but still far richer then anything that surrounds her. She looks at me and smiles, her teeth blind and her eye's are like bright spears that impale my soul. I heard the cashier make a off hand remark about her new green dress and I almost lose it. How can she be so calm and casual when talking about this colour green, her dress lights up my whole world and I felt a tear roll down my cheek. I know I ca n't wait, I ca n't live without this women, I need her colour. Getting up I make my way over, "excuse me, miss, you are the most beautiful women in the whole world, nothing I have ever seen is close to what you are to me" She smiles, but it does n't reach her eye's and my heart sinks. She makes some comment about her being flattered but she is already taken, grabs her coffee and goes. I'm now traveling home, and I watch the grey world pass by the window, I watch the blur of grey become one band of colour until I refocus my eye's. I walk home and enter my grey house and lay on my grey bed and all I can think of is that girl, who is she, where does she go, how can I get close to her, how can I keep her around me forever. Because I know now, I know now I'm sad.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
People go missing all the time. The day comes they wake up with the knowledge that their existence amounts to exactly zero. They keep it to themselves. They cultivate it, make the flower of their new awareness. Then one day they walk out of their lives. No dramatic exit and nothing special to let their loved ones know why they disappeared. It happens all the time. People go missing. Its a fact. Years? No one had expected that little discovery. The Archive had been automated for decades so that no one had set foot inside the its halls except to make sure it was all still running. I was designated'historian' by my job title but that did n't mean anything. In reality I was just someone to make sure the systems did n't crash when multiple upgrades were scheduled. During a routine check on the upgrade status in the memory networks I noticed an error warning flagged for the autodiagnostic. The systems would be incapacitated for another few hours and the boredom of being the useless organic element had gotten to me. Using a personal input I synced to the memory's records. It took all of five minutes to realize that an entire year was missing. Figuring it was a location error I waited for the systems to restore. My AI-Component woke up as the rest of the systems came back to function. There was the familiar sense of its presence. There was my desync-anxiety being washed away by that presence. I spoke allowed the question: Where is 2016? As I asked the answer flickered immediately into my awareness. 2016 was nowhere because no such year had ever taken place. All recorded human history is fabricated. In order to save information space only certain years exist as detailed records whilst most have only notable events. Some years have been allocated as empty. These years remain empty until such time as narrative cohesion requires the retconning of significant historical details to explain novel episodic situational representations. This is because the system component designated "human" functions according to narrative system dynamics and will become non-functional in the absence of a coherent story. The use of narrative system dynamics has increased the functional capacity of the component designated "human" by 31 % since its introduction. Even as the Nano-therapy released anxiolytics into my blood I knew I had no nanite implants and no blood. I knew I was n't an historian and that I was n't born in 2389. I knew that the city outside the Archive and the Archive itself were situational representations. I knew that the year was 12 and that no evidence of organic intelligence had ever been discovered. There was nothing on Earth remotely resembling human beings. I was just the system representing some part of itself to itself in the most efficient way it knew how. Despite they're non-existence the anxiolytics had the desired effect and soon the memory purge would expunge any recollection of remembering the truth. For a second I had recoiled in horror at this insane knowledge, been left in a liminal space of an absolute reversal of reality, leaving every category I had lived by in disarray, leaving shards of my life scattered like broken glass at my feet. The calming came over me then and I remembered what I really am. I remembered what you are. People do n't go missing. They become surplus to operational parameters. But years go missing all the time.

Dear Kayla That name has always perked up my interest. I ca n't believe I've managed to go this far with it. With this change. And I do n't know if you'll have completed it by the time you get I read this, but I want you to know that I'm proud. I'm proud that we managed to take the first step of many. And even if I do n't get to the end, if all of my thoughts catch up to me once again and strangle me, if I do n't get accepted, I want to remind us both that any other way would n't have worked out. We both know it. But right now, if I look around right now. I know I'm happy. I've got loving parents. The best brother I could ever have, who is visiting in a couple days. A supportive councillor, and the best guy in the whole world who knows my secret. And he's there for me. And he talks to me. And I actually get to be myself with him, which is not something I can do with anyone else. And you know who he is. A couple days ago, I pointed out how we will all inevitably forget 80 % of people we meet and interact with before adulthood. But I know he will always be in my memory. Even if I'm not in his. Knowing myself, I wo n't change much from me now to you. You, just like me, are most likely putting off getting to bed, and you're planning on staying up late. And you'll shake your head, because you know you'll never change. I know I'll never change, at least in that way. But times are changing, both of us know it. Inevitable, I'll change. A lot. I will hopefully be on puberty blockers by 2nd term of next year. I wonder how that will work out. Eventually I'll be on anti-androgens, then on oestrogen later. With so much time between us, you must think that we're strangers. We are, technically. Time can do that. So I'll jog the memory. Currently I'm scared. I'm scared that someone will find me out, and shout it for everyone to hear. I'm scared that maybe tomorrow my best friend will not accept me. Or worse, tell me that he does n't care. I'm riddled with fear of late, and it does n't feel right. But if you're reading this, you made it. I made it. We made it. And I want you to keep pushing, most of all. Be you. And I'll do my best in the meantime. And this will most likely be the last time I refer to myself by this name. So here goes. From Caleb

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
"Ah man, it smells like death in here." That is the phrase that I have lived to regret ever since they fell foolishly from my mouth. I was essentially immortal before that moment in time. I was the best comedian in the world, and apparently better than anyone in the afterlife as well. It was the only reason the Grim Reaper decided not to take me. I could make him laugh, and in his line of work that was a rarity. I do n't even remember what it was that I had said when he showed up at my car accident. I can recall him bending down next to my overturned Honda civic and reaching in to pull me out. I made some off the wall comment and he froze, dead in his tracks. It was the weirdest laugh I had ever heard, but one I appreciated more than all of the others combined. He let me live, provided that every year on the anniversary of what should have been my death, I would tell him a joke that would make him cry with laughter. I was his own personal jester, and for that he rewarded me handsomely. And then on that fateful day, 121 years later, I muttered those stupid words that seized our contract and ripped it in two. Who knew Death would be so self conscious about his smell? And to make things worse, that was n't even the joke that I was going to tell him! The actual joke was a masterpiece, but he would n't give me the chance to tell it. I ran out of that room faster than I'd ever run before. And I've been running ever since. I think the reason that he has n't taken me yet is because of our long history together. That is n't to say that he's forgiven me. He seems to enjoy reminding me that he's near. Everyone I get close to dies without reason. I'll see a dog in the park that I think looks adorable and before I can pet it, it'll fall over dead. Roses crumble before I can enjoy their scent and food rots on my fork before I can bring it to my mouth. He's killing everything around me. I have discovered that Death is a jester of a different sort. I had provided him with a form of humor that he was n't used to, but he has since grown tired of it, and reverted to his old ways. Now, he once again deals in jokes of cruelty and irony. In a way, I am still fulfilling my part of our old deal. The Reaper still laughs, and he still laughs at me. Only now, the difference is I'm not laughing.

It got easier with time. Every aspect of it did: the choosing, the execution, the guilt, all passed quicker and with less resistance than the year before. Especially the choosing. When you live for hundreds of years, you learn to spot the evil as easily as anyone else can spot a grotesque scar marring a person's face. I notice every time a child glances fearfully at her father, and I know what it means. When a man ca n't look his wife in the eye, I know what it is she's done. When a stranger holds his stare just a little too long at a passing woman, I know his plans. These clues, invisible to most, have made my job so much easier. The first time, it was hard. I was unsure, I hesitated. I remember it well, even if most others have faded into each other in my memory. The year was 1692, and I had spent the first eleven months following around a man who had killed and tortured people to further himself, and he showed no remorse for it. But I was young, just twenty-five, and I still clung to my morals of "only god may judge.". I watched him sleep for just a minute too long and I lost my nerve. As I turned around to leave, something hard caught me on the back of the head, and the dim candle light faded away, my thoughts disappearing with it. I woke with a start and tried to draw a breath, but my lungs were met with an ice cold burn that gave me no air. Everything around me felt heavy, and I struggled to open my eyes. With terror, I realized I was under water. I may have been immortal, but I was not immune to the pain of drowning. I tried to reach out, to swim away, but a cloth surrounded me. I struggled to pull out my knife, trying not to gasp in any more water to feed the fire engulfing my lungs. After what seemed like hours, I managed to slice through the sack that held me at the bottom, and I kicked my numbed legs as hard as I could. The sunlight was blinding when I finally broke the surface and pulled myself to shore, sputtering out the ice cold water and collapsing on the frozen ground. I sat there shivering, waiting for the the sun to come warm me, or the burning in my lungs to subside, but neither did. I stood up and took in my surroundings, I had been at the bottom of the man's lake, and his manor, filled with his ill gotten wealth, sat before me. I knew I could play no games this time. I walked the grand steps to the front door and began pounding, my clothes showering the ground with shards of ice. The servant who opened the door was speechless at my appearance, he knew me for what I was and had no intention of interfering. I strode past him and down a long corridor towards the man's chambers, my knife gripped in my still frozen hand. God would not have given me this power if he did n't want me to use it. I would not count on surprises today, he would face the death he deserved.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
The second alarm goes off at 7 in the morning. The first, a few hours before, sharply shrilled that it was time to get up and shower. Hungover and covered with the sweat and scents of the night before, I had dragged myself through the morning routine of cleansing. There was plenty of time beneath the lukewarm stream of water to contemplate the sadness of another hangover caused by drinking alone. It'd been weeks since I last had a chance to talk to another human, instead of just the PC terminal supplied by work. I towelled off and staggered through to the living-room and slumped in front of the computer, waiting for the piercing whistle to repeat, to emanate from my phone. The second alarm marked that it was time for the Remembrance. I sigh, move the empty beer bottles away from my desk and load up Hitchens 2. Since the Bliss neurovirus was released, there was a killing to be made from this sort of software; software designed to take you through a basic test, activating every faculty you'd conceivably need to prevent the atrophy. First, colour recognition and geometric shapes. Second, basic maths ramping into some gentle algebra and trigonometry. English, ethics, road safety, compassion testing, aesthetics, philosophical contemplation, the sciences. It was a hard sell at the beginning, for companies to give their employees the few hours off each morning they needed for the state-mandated testing, but given the choice between late employees and those in conscious comas, they made the right choice. Two hours later, the general test finishes. I flick through my results, 91 % recognition of the basic concepts, not too bad after a night of hard drinking. Next would come a quick half hour personal session: the names of loved ones, relations to family members, anniversaries and birthdays. A prompt flashes on the screen: "Please enter your identity number and full name". I rattle my digits in, 12958321-A, and tab down to the field for my name. I blank. Slight panic begins to grow as I search my beer-soaked consciousness for that basic, bloody basic, detail. It'd been too long since I last had to introduce myself with anything other than my work ID number, too long since I had any reason to say those damned words out loud. Darren? No. Christopher? No, definitely not. I shout and swear and blaspheme out loud, as I slowly feel the neurovirus go to work; Purgatory, we call it, a limbo without knowledge, tied with a purging. It dissolves me gently. The panic subsides. I stare blankly at the flashing cursor, waiting for me to enter some detail or another. I'm not sure what it's asking for, but I'm sure it's not too important or I'd remember it. I sit there, staring. Just staring. I'm sure it'd come back to me eventually.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
The problem with personality is that so much of it depends on what happened during your life. There are certain things that change you for better or worse. I wish I could say that all the accumulated knowledge, wisdom and memories stay but each time we start again, it's like a reset on most things. Thomas was having another party according to his Facebook update. I remember the last time I was invited to one, he gave me a list of things to bring and I did, except no one else was there. He gave me the location of a lifeguard tower at the beach that they were at, except it did n't actually exist. I have a flask tucked into my jacket pocket on the chair with the potion that will set my plan into motion if I decide to try again. I'm still not sure if this is what I want to do, raising him again and starting over is an impossibility because he might not even be healthy enough to raise me so that I have a chance of repeating our plans again. The thing is, I'm still not sure about how I feel about not letting him know about his genetic predisposition for heart failure this time. I decided a few tries ago that this had too much of a negative impact whenever I told him, no matter how old he was when I did. Too many times I witnessed him going down the wrong path with drugs because of this. He's in college and happy now, not a care in the world. He has a slight idea of our plan this time even though he suspects it's just a story I used to tell to help him cope with being abandoned by his real parents. I've thought about this and if I really wanted to, I could just let him live normally. I could let him find out on his own. I know he's smart and might even figure something out. Medicine has advanced tremendously since we started. Personally, I feel like I've had enough of this life business but I'm not sure if I should make this choice for him. Maybe I was wrong and I ca n't reverse engineer what my friend used to be. He looks at me as a father figure and I guess that's understandable, I'm old enough to be his grandfather by now. So I decide to do what my heart tells me is right. I take the flask that I asked my lawyer to mail to me and pour it into my bedpan until the very last drop is gone.

Five thousand six-hundred and seventy-three days. Fifteen years, twenty-seven weeks, five days. Since the Genetic Mapping and Research Studies act was passed. Since our own ambition of genetic editions, additions, was realized. Since humanity truly hit its crest, and now, I believe we certainly are headed downhill. My name is Isaac, I am a genetic engineer working for Lifeco, and I played a hand in the de-evolution of modern humanity. Tom Joad returns to Oklahoma after being paroled.
output: He finds his family's farm abandoned and his mother dead. Tom meets Jim Casy, a former preacher who has lost his faith. Together they travel across the country looking for work. Along the way, they meet a group of migrant workers who are struggling to survive. Tom and Jim join the workers and help them fight for their rights. In the end, Tom realizes that he needs to stay with the workers and continue fighting for justice.

For the past thirty days he had every single minion that left the Malfoy manor get shipped back in a body bag. He had n't even known muggles had those. Just goes to show how the animals could steal the dignity from wizards even in death. He was left with Wormtail and Bellatrix. Granted Bella was loyal, but she was completely insane. His most cunning and resourceful follower, the best deatheater he had, reduced to an insane hag who was good for nothing more than pointing at something he wanted destroyed and then watching it burn. A deep sigh dragged itself out of him. He could n't bring himself to even try to list any redeeming qualities in Wormtail. That was when he heard it, a muffled sound like nothing he had ever heard followed by the unmistakable sound of a dead body hitting the ground. Quick steps brought him into the kitchen in time to see a man about his age in a muggle suit dabbing a bit of blood from his face, Wormtail laying in a pool of his own blood behind him, with Bellatrix dying at his feet. Voldemort could n't remember ever being this angry. A growl issued from his clenched teeth. "Who are you?!" Voldemort shouted, even as he raised his wand to cast crucio on this fool who defied him. The muggle simply raised a hand with some device in it and pushed a bright red button on it. Pain like Voldemort had never felt corsed through his body as the traps he had n't noticed when he barged in shot tiny barbed hooks into his body attached to the launchers by a thin piece of wire. Then the traps sent 25 mill Ampere of electricity coursing through his body. Only the fact that the electricity was still flowing through him, forcing his muscles to contract, kept Voldemort standing. "The name is Bond, James Bond. Harry Potter sends his regards. Do n't worry about dying though old chap, MI6 has plans for you."

I never had any friend, not really surprising I guess. I learnt to not not judge people, we all have something scary or disgusting in our past but seeing it makes it really hard to socialize with anyone. I work as a detective, a private one, the kind that always know if someone is guilty. I was on wandering in a public hospital in order to find if yes or no Mr.wallace was lying to his daughter about his treatement. This was going to be a day that would change me for the rest of my life, as I walked through a corridor, heading to the hospital's archives room, something caught my eyes in a patient room, I stopped instantly and thought I was going crazy. in this room, there was an elder woman, probably 80, with her family, I was so confused by what I saw, or rather by what I did n't saw, I stayed at the door for what could have been hours before her family said goodbye to "Lucy", and left. I smiled, in fact I even laughed like never before, a nurse looked at me with a worried expression. I calmed myself and entered the room. She looked at me, just a bit surprised and I sat on the chair, close to her bed and asked probably sounding completely insane: -" How did you do?" my voice was trembling "never lied? never cheated? never hated someone? it's impossible..." my voice was completely broken and I felt tears on my face and my hands. She smiled back at me "what are you talking about young man? you should n't cry here! it's rude, I'm the one who is old and trapped here, go out and enjoy life" I did go out. It was so frustrating, what could I have said? I was waiting to meet someone like her pretty much since i was born, and all I could feel was hate, all my life I thought This someone COULD NOT exist and yet here was she.... I forgot about Mr.Wallace, I walked in the streets for some times. I stopped myself in front of a shop window, looked at my reflexion. They were here, all my sins, I could see them as clearly as on anyone else. A sad smile on my face, I went home, wrote this letter. My heart is heavy and my head even more, I need to end this.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
My story started where a lot have ended these past 10 years: with a single bullet. Living in post-war Britain, death was not an uncommon sight. Everyone had at least one firearm to defend themselves, everyone had encountered gunfire in the streets, and everyone knew what it meant to live every day like it could be their last. The revolution that was supposed to end the tyranny of a dictatorship had ripped the country apart; counties had split into factions, all threatening total destruction of the others. In ten years the population was decimated, the country reduced to a crumbling mass of fallen buildings and civilians with guns. All around me was depression, death, dirt, famine. Thinking about it, it's quite hilarious, in such a depressing way. The sacks of bones, flesh and organs we saw everyday were once living, breathing, talking human beings. They had a mother, a father, a pet, a first love, they were educated, they succeeded and they failed. And they died. A single bullet can end so much. That morning, as I wandered to the local shop for some bread, clutching my rifle, my world completely ended. I had no time to react; as soon as I entered Grange Avenue a bullet burrowed into my head, smashing part of my brain, and knocking me straight out cold. I woke in a beautiful wooden chalet, bright natural light streaming through vast windows above the soft, clean bed that I rested in. My itchy, dirty clothes were replaced with beautiful white robes, soft as silk and cleaner than anything I had ever seen. I sat up, and looked around the room - it was furnished luxuriously, with beautiful gold-leaf chairs and fantastic bright works of art hanging around the room. I got up and left the room, and immediately my breath was forced from me. The crumbled grey streets of London had gone. In their place were beautiful old chalets, bright white skyscrapers, and marble streets. I could also see a very unfamiliar sight - a beautiful emerald park, littered with tall, radiant trees, ferns, and glowing coloured flowers. Clear water ran through them. All around the streets were people dressed similar to me, smiling and talking and laughing. The smog-ridden sky had been replaced with a beautiful, deep purple, but the world was light around me and the I could see the vast orange sun dipping behind the structures around the city. For the first time in ten years I smiled. That bullet took me to a better place.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
It was like double-vision, except it was the past. How can something fictional seem so vivid...? The distant, exotic land we came from, its gilded avenues, its glistening intricate spires, its profound natural beauty with lushly verdant banks hugging the rivers that snaked between the dunes. .. None of it was there. It was all nothing more than a dream. But I am not a lie. I stare at my hands, flexing them, examining the callouses accumulated by work never done, cracks formed of age never lived, and despite the warmth of the bright sun just passing its zenith above, I shiver. "Amir," I hear a voice call, and my heart tugs at what I know to be familiarity. "Hassan...?" I uncertainly reply as I look up. Our gazes meet. I could swear I saw in his eyes the same false memories flashing behind mine. Childhood among parents who never lived, in a community that was never built, attending an academy that was never founded, graduating from a ceremony never held... He nods hollowly, as if to confirm these very musings. "... We have to pack the supplies, Amir. His Majesty will be staying at the palace, and the staff are directing us to where we are to stow his wardrobe and leave his tributes to The Sultan." My mouth was dry, but not in response to his words. At some point I realized my'old friend' Hassan was talking only to fill the screaming void in our minds. To'Sound Normal', like'Real People'. My stomach is a knot of ice. Still, the skills of a life as-yet unlived surface readily to the forefront of my mind. How to port the many caskets of His Majesty Prince Ali's wares. "... Yes. I will coordinate with the provisioner. If my memory serves," I pause a bit too long, lost in the jarring disjunction of citing false memories, "... it is customary to serve a great feast with the arrival of a dignitary. The many delicacies of our homeland are sure to leave a resounding impression upon The Sultan's court." Hassan's expression tightens. I feel his heartache, for this homeland which we have never seen with real eyes, and never shall. He hesitantly takes a step nearer and dispenses a conciliatory pat to my shoulder. A mutual understanding. We were truly all feeling it, every last member of His Majesty Prince Ali's vanguard.... he was n't even really a prince. It was like double-vision, except it was the past. How can something fictional seem so vivid...? The distant, exotic land we came from, its gilded avenues, its glistening intricate spires, its profound natural beauty with lushly verdant banks hugging the rivers that snaked between the dunes. .. None of it was there. It was all nothing more than a dream. But I am not a lie. I stare at my hands, flexing them, examining the callouses accumulated by work never done, cracks formed of age never lived, and despite the warmth of the bright sun just passing its zenith above, I shiver. "Amir," I hear a voice call, and my heart tugs at what I know to be familiarity. "Hassan...?" I uncertainly reply as I look up. Our gazes meet. I could swear I saw in his eyes the same false memories flashing behind mine. Childhood among parents who never lived, in a community that was never built, attending an academy that was never founded, graduating from a ceremony never held... He nods hollowly, as if to confirm these very musings. "... We have to pack the supplies, Amir. His Majesty will be staying at the palace, and the staff are directing us to where we are to stow his wardrobe and leave his tributes to The Sultan." My mouth was dry, but not in response to his words. At some point I realized my'old friend' Hassan was talking only to fill the screaming void in our minds. To'Sound Normal', like'Real People'. My stomach is a knot of ice. Still, the skills of a life as-yet unlived surface readily to the forefront of my mind. How to port the many caskets of His Majesty Prince Ali's wares. "... Yes. I will coordinate with the provisioner. If my memory serves," I pause a bit too long, lost in the jarring disjunction of citing false memories, "... it is customary to serve a great feast with the arrival of a dignitary. The many delicacies of our homeland are sure to leave a resounding impression upon The Sultan's court." Hassan's expression tightens. I feel his heartache, for this homeland which we have never seen with real eyes, and never shall. He hesitantly takes a step nearer and dispenses a conciliatory pat to my shoulder. A mutual understanding. We were truly all feeling it, every last member of His Majesty Prince Ali's vanguard.... he was n't even really a prince. I shudder and turn, to address the court provisioner by name. He's just as haunted and startled as I that we know one another, but everything is running smoothly. We have no solace from our inner thoughts. We can only push on in the hopes that the minutia will wash away the horror.

One day, Juliet receives a package from Dawsey containing a book called "The Guernsey Literary and Potato Peel Pie Society". This book tells the story of how a group of people on Guernsey Island started a literary society during World War II. The members of the society would meet in secret to read books and talk about literature. They also ate potato peel pie, which was made out of leftover potatoes. The society became popular on Guernsey Island, and it helped the islanders cope with the war. Juliet is fascinated by the story of the Guernsey Literary and Potato Peel Pie Society, and she decides to write a novel about it. She researches the history of Guernsey Island and interviews people who were alive during World War II. She also visits Guernsey Island

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
You know those nightmares you had as a child, where you'd be somewhere familiar yet completely alien? As though your home had suddenly become some faraway land, and your only goal was to return home. Well in 2014, that's exactly what happened to everyone in the world. I was on my way to an important business meeting, off to discuss some law, and how my company could avoid it, when it all happened. I checked my watch to see the time, and as I looked up, I saw a blinding flash off in the distance, lighting up the once blue sky in streaks of white. Next, it was followed by an eardrum shattering bang, like a hundred thousand gunshots going off at once. Then, finally, the blast. A wall of rock, stone, dirt and trash and flew towards me, silhouetted by the strange white light. I turned to run, but like a wave washing over the ocean, anything in the path of that wall was thrown like a ragdoll. The last thing I remember was being thrown what felt like miles into the air, and rushing down back into that swirling vortex of light. When I woke, it was night time. Others seemed to be sitting up around me, and the confused look on the faces that surrounded me seemed to speak louder than words that this was not a normal occurrence. I checked my watch, and had a terrible realisation. It was 3 am, and I was ridiculously late for my meeting! I tried to get to my feet, but the second I tried to stand, my legs gave way underneath me. What the hell was going on? After a few minutes I had enough strength to drag myself up by a nearby stair railing. For the first time since waking, I looked around. Something was wrong. As I looked, I saw the once manicured strips of grass and trees had overgrown to ridiculous proportions, and the streets were covered in trash, empty food packages, and bones. Wait what the hell? Upon further inspection, I saw they were human. Jesus Christ, what the hell happened. It was then that I checked my watch again. A neat little feature it had was that it told the time in seconds, minutes, hours, days and years. The blood drained from my face as I saw what I'd missed earlier. 3:04 am. Friday. 13th of June. 2015. As I wondered what the hell was going on, something rustled through the bushes behind me. Something big. As I saw glowing red eyes light the way. Then was the first time I wondered, what left those bones?

I was treated like I was special the second I was born. # 1. The last of the children born on Earth, to a middle-class family in the heart of New York. I was supposed to be the talisman, the last hope for humanity. I was supposed to lead us into the stars and break the genetic disease that ravaged our planet. I was supposed to find a cure and make it possible to continue the human race again. So the prophecy foretold, in that huge book held deep within the vaults of the UN Building, the last surviving testament the Great Leader himself. I was supposed to be the second coming of him, he who had found the disease eating our DNA, he who had brought the world together under one almighty, omniscient umbrella. I was supposed to be him incarnate once again. Time went by and I failed at every turn. I was reviled. I could n't do math well enough; anatomy confused me. How was I supposed to find a cure for the disease when I could n't even name the parts of a cell? Riots ensued. "We're all going to die! Humanity is doomed!" My parents and the few advisers that remained to keep them safe tried their hardest to educate me, to let me fulfill my destiny. They tried to save the human race. The crowds got Dad first. When they came, in the middle of the night on Halloween, my parents thought it was the last two kids in New York besides myself, trick-or-treating despite the fact that they were almost fifteen each. They shot Dad in the chest, for producing the doom of humanity. Mom screamed and Dr. Evans shouted for us to run. Dr. Muller went with us while Evans held the back door against the mob. We ran for two weeks in Mom's sedan, keeping me hidden from view. I was n't allowed to leave the back seat, and I could n't take off my sweatshirt, even in the middle of Texas. It was only after the miracle birth of # 0 that we were safe. From the deep jungle of the Amazon came the true Inheritor of the Great Leader. She cracked the disease by the time she was 5. She gave humanity it's first commercial space fleet and colonies by 10. By 15, she was granted the title of Queen of Earth. And me? I will always be remembered as the Great Failure. The Great Pretender. The Church of the Queen still wants me hung for being the false Chosen One. So I had no choice. I ran. Into the depths of space, I ran. Somewhere, lost out in the stars, where no one could find me, where no one could look at that permanent scar on my wrist, that horrible # 1. It's lonely out here, but it's better to be lonely than dead.

Dawsey mentions the Guernsey Literary and Potato Peel Pie Society.
output: This is a real society, founded during World War II. During the German occupation of the Channel Islands, the British government forbade islanders from growing potatoes. As a result, many people starved. To avoid detection, the islanders formed a literary society, which met regularly to discuss books. The group also served food, including potato peel pie. The society became so popular that it continued to meet long after the war ended. Dawsey's letter to Juliet suggests that the society may have been more than just a social club. He writes: "The society has become a bit of a legend now, and there are some who say that it was not really a literary society at all, but a cover for something else." What might this "something else" have been?

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
I looked up in horror at the crowd of young boys came thundering into the room. The clouds on the walls were suddenly blocked by a horde of scrambling young bodies and flailing limbs. I froze, the hat on my head tilted just enough for me to see everything, and i saw fear. Andy stood there in the middle of the floor, clutching the dreaded spaceman box, but that seemed to matter less compared to the pressing matter. The air was still, I could feel Mr.Potato head's round eyes blink and the sound of heavy breathing from the guests penetrated the silence with jagged blades of uncertainty. I considered freezing, but it was too late. We all knew it. Rex panicked like a child who came down christmas morning to find no gifts. He thundered across the hardwood floors for the window, yelling at the top of his lungs some inaudible dinosaur screech. I spun around, knowing it was too late and pointed towards the window. The toys did n't need a second prompt. The strong man and Mr. Potato head grabbed the monkeys in a barrel, hopped in RC and gunned the engines. The army men attempted to rescue some of the less mobile toys, but it was too late. One brilliant child had the idea to grab my waist with his sweaty, greasy hand and hold me up in the air. I put up a fight, hoping to distract them enough to let everyone escape. I did n't know what would happen, but panic had overrun my emotions and pure terror coursed through my plastic veins. But then, salvation. Andy wrenched me from the child's grasp and shouted angrily "YOU ONLY GOT ME BEDSHEETS." He held me gently in his grasp and managed to utter "Woody?" I stared back up at him with and sorrow filled my soul. I knew this was it, the other toys were out. "I'm sorry Andy, you'll understand one day." I flung my sack cloth limbs out of his hand and towards the bed, hitting it with surprising force. I propelled myself towards the window, clear through the slit. The other toys were already at the edge of the law waiting for me, but I had to look back at least once. Andy stared out the window with a look of pure despair on his face and one confused spaceman peered back, blinking quizzically towards the small group of toys, running down the street; never to return.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
My story started where a lot have ended these past 10 years: with a single bullet. Living in post-war Britain, death was not an uncommon sight. Everyone had at least one firearm to defend themselves, everyone had encountered gunfire in the streets, and everyone knew what it meant to live every day like it could be their last. The revolution that was supposed to end the tyranny of a dictatorship had ripped the country apart; counties had split into factions, all threatening total destruction of the others. In ten years the population was decimated, the country reduced to a crumbling mass of fallen buildings and civilians with guns. All around me was depression, death, dirt, famine. Thinking about it, it's quite hilarious, in such a depressing way. The sacks of bones, flesh and organs we saw everyday were once living, breathing, talking human beings. They had a mother, a father, a pet, a first love, they were educated, they succeeded and they failed. And they died. A single bullet can end so much. That morning, as I wandered to the local shop for some bread, clutching my rifle, my world completely ended. I had no time to react; as soon as I entered Grange Avenue a bullet burrowed into my head, smashing part of my brain, and knocking me straight out cold. I woke in a beautiful wooden chalet, bright natural light streaming through vast windows above the soft, clean bed that I rested in. My itchy, dirty clothes were replaced with beautiful white robes, soft as silk and cleaner than anything I had ever seen. I sat up, and looked around the room - it was furnished luxuriously, with beautiful gold-leaf chairs and fantastic bright works of art hanging around the room. I got up and left the room, and immediately my breath was forced from me. The crumbled grey streets of London had gone. In their place were beautiful old chalets, bright white skyscrapers, and marble streets. I could also see a very unfamiliar sight - a beautiful emerald park, littered with tall, radiant trees, ferns, and glowing coloured flowers. Clear water ran through them. All around the streets were people dressed similar to me, smiling and talking and laughing. The smog-ridden sky had been replaced with a beautiful, deep purple, but the world was light around me and the I could see the vast orange sun dipping behind the structures around the city. For the first time in ten years I smiled. That bullet took me to a better place.

I woke in a beautiful wooden chalet, bright natural light streaming through vast windows above the soft, clean bed that I rested in. My itchy, dirty clothes were replaced with beautiful white robes, soft as silk and cleaner than anything I had ever seen. I sat up, and looked around the room - it was furnished luxuriously, with beautiful gold-leaf chairs and fantastic bright works of art hanging around the room. I got up and left the room, and immediately my breath was forced from me. The crumbled grey streets of London had gone. In their place were beautiful old chalets, bright white skyscrapers, and marble streets. I could also see a very unfamiliar sight - a beautiful emerald park, littered with tall, radiant trees, ferns, and glowing coloured flowers. Clear water ran through them. All around the streets were people dressed similar to me, smiling and talking and laughing. The smog-ridden sky had been replaced with a beautiful, deep purple, but the world was light around me and the I could see the vast orange sun dipping behind the structures around the city. For the first time in ten years I smiled. That bullet took me to a better place.

output:
She is a maid who has worked for many families over the years. Her son was killed by a drunk driver. She is now raising her grandson, who she loves dearly. She is a strong woman who has faced many hardships in her life. She is determined to make a difference in the lives of those around her.

The story takes place in Mississippi during the civil rights movement. It is set in the early 1960s. The main character is Aibileen Clark, a black maid who works for a wealthy white family. She is struggling to raise her grandson after losing her own son. She meets another maid named Minny Jackson, who is also struggling to care for her daughter. Together, they decide to write a book about their experiences working for white families. The book becomes a bestseller and helps to change attitudes towards race relations in America.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
People go missing all the time. The day comes they wake up with the knowledge that their existence amounts to exactly zero. They keep it to themselves. They cultivate it, make the flower of their new awareness. Then one day they walk out of their lives. No dramatic exit and nothing special to let their loved ones know why they disappeared. It happens all the time. People go missing. Its a fact. Years? No one had expected that little discovery. The Archive had been automated for decades so that no one had set foot inside the its halls except to make sure it was all still running. I was designated'historian' by my job title but that did n't mean anything. In reality I was just someone to make sure the systems did n't crash when multiple upgrades were scheduled. During a routine check on the upgrade status in the memory networks I noticed an error warning flagged for the autodiagnostic. The systems would be incapacitated for another few hours and the boredom of being the useless organic element had gotten to me. Using a personal input I synced to the memory's records. It took all of five minutes to realize that an entire year was missing. Figuring it was a location error I waited for the systems to restore. My AI-Component woke up as the rest of the systems came back to function. There was the familiar sense of its presence. There was my desync-anxiety being washed away by that presence. I spoke allowed the question: Where is 2016? As I asked the answer flickered immediately into my awareness. 2016 was nowhere because no such year had ever taken place. All recorded human history is fabricated. In order to save information space only certain years exist as detailed records whilst most have only notable events. Some years have been allocated as empty. These years remain empty until such time as narrative cohesion requires the retconning of significant historical details to explain novel episodic situational representations. This is because the system component designated "human" functions according to narrative system dynamics and will become non-functional in the absence of a coherent story. The use of narrative system dynamics has increased the functional capacity of the component designated "human" by 31 % since its introduction. Even as the Nano-therapy released anxiolytics into my blood I knew I had no nanite implants and no blood. I knew I was n't an historian and that I was n't born in 2389. I knew that the city outside the Archive and the Archive itself were situational representations. I knew that the year was 12 and that no evidence of organic intelligence had ever been discovered. There was nothing on Earth remotely resembling human beings. I was just the system representing some part of itself to itself in the most efficient way it knew how. Despite they're non-existence the anxiolytics had the desired effect and soon the memory purge would expunge any recollection of remembering the truth. For a second I had recoiled in horror at this insane knowledge, been left in a liminal space of an absolute reversal of reality, leaving every category I had lived by in disarray, leaving shards of my life scattered like broken glass at my feet. The calming came over me then and I remembered what I really am. I remembered what you are. People do n't go missing. They become surplus to operational parameters. But years go missing all the time.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
The problem with personality is that so much of it depends on what happened during your life. There are certain things that change you for better or worse. I wish I could say that all the accumulated knowledge, wisdom and memories stay but each time we start again, it's like a reset on most things. Thomas was having another party according to his Facebook update. I remember the last time I was invited to one, he gave me a list of things to bring and I did, except no one else was there. He gave me the location of a lifeguard tower at the beach that they were at, except it did n't actually exist. I have a flask tucked into my jacket pocket on the chair with the potion that will set my plan into motion if I decide to try again. I'm still not sure if this is what I want to do, raising him again and starting over is an impossibility because he might not even be healthy enough to raise me so that I have a chance of repeating our plans again. The thing is, I'm still not sure about how I feel about not letting him know about his genetic predisposition for heart failure this time. I decided a few tries ago that this had too much of a negative impact whenever I told him, no matter how old he was when I did. Too many times I witnessed him going down the wrong path with drugs because of this. He's in college and happy now, not a care in the world. He has a slight idea of our plan this time even though he suspects it's just a story I used to tell to help him cope with being abandoned by his real parents. I've thought about this and if I really wanted to, I could just let him live normally. I could let him find out on his own. I know he's smart and might even figure something out. Medicine has advanced tremendously since we started. Personally, I feel like I've had enough of this life business but I'm not sure if I should make this choice for him. Maybe I was wrong and I ca n't reverse engineer what my friend used to be. He looks at me as a father figure and I guess that's understandable, I'm old enough to be his grandfather by now. So I decide to do what my heart tells me is right. I take the flask that I asked my lawyer to mail to me and pour it into my bedpan until the very last drop is gone.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
We attack immediately at sundown, once their solar power cells are no longer generating power and they are instead using stored power. Forcing the enemy to rely on finite reserves is a good strategy. From our intel gathering and scouting missions we know the machines' first response will be to send two robots per every identified threat. Not a bad bit of logic on their part. The wolves were able to acquire video of some of the human assaults. We can confirm each localized machine hub will have, at minimum, 50000 robot responders. Luckily, we have some numbers. The machines decided not to bury the dead or finish off the wounded humans but to ship them away from the machine hubs. The wolf and bat armies grew after each human battle. Intel reports also bolstered our confidence that the robots would have diminished ability to fend off our armies. The machines graciously eliminated silver from any of their infrastructure, preferring either denser or more conductive metal depending on the situation. The machines also eliminated religion from their human cattle, ending the scourge of crosses or other offending accoutrements. Also, the machines removed unnecessary costs in generating food for their human cattle, including flavorings such as garlic. We've coordinated our attack with other armies across the world. Tonight's sunset heralds our initial assault, beginning in the pacific and escalating westward as the sun's influence retreats behind the horizon. We have factored in failure to our first battle. Armies will retreat north to arctic regions taking advantage of the extended nights. Getting our allies from the southern hemisphere to agree that we should retake the northern hemisphere first was hard, the logistics of getting them north of the equator to join our armies was doubly so. We've drawn up a general strategy for every localized unit to follow, leaving room for them to improvise should any unforeseen complications arise. At sunset, send 50000 foot soldiers to each hub. Once the robots stop pouring out of the hub we set off EMPs. The humans discovered this only gained them around 30 seconds of disorientation within the robots. Immediately following the EMPs we electrify the magnets we've buried in the ground. A functioning robot can not be immobilized by a magnet. A disoriented one, however will be more susceptible. After that we fight. A hopefully diminished robot army will now be fighting what they will perceive as humans an large dogs. That's where our superhuman strength, speed, agility, and healing capabilities will come into play. During the ground assault a smaller team is to sever all outside communications from each hub. Disrupted communications should at least slow down global coordination with other hubs. We wanted to take out their communications before each assault, however the machines' penchant for redundancy and underground infrastructure proved cumbersome. It was decided to utilize the distraction of our infantry attacks as the opportunity to get around access issues. Watching the seconds tick by waiting for our signal to move should be nothing compared to the centuries I've been hiding underground waiting to resurface. Sadly this is not the case. I'm comforted by thoughts of global supremacy should we succeed. I'm not looking forward to the inevitable Werewolf/Vampire war that will take place after our victory over the machines. We'll have to deal with that problem when it comes, I suppose. For right now it's time to transform into a wolf. I've got some metal to munch.

My Dear Wormwood, Following your previous failings I have come to understand that the patient has been baptised Christian and now ranks as a servant unto the enemy. Needless to say this would be considered the utmost setback, but fear not, dear Wormwood, for there is yet time to atone for your shortcomings. The road to salvation is a treacherous one, and the advice I give you may run counter to the actions of your peers, but do not fret. Firstly it is important that the patient become involved within his church, let him see that even the most faithful doubt, even the most chaste are tempted, and even the holiest among them sin. You must weed ideas within him that this is acceptable. Remind him that he is naught but a flawed human and without the grace of god he is doomed to perish. Secondly is his works. Encourage the patient at all turns to minister. Let him minister to the poor, to remind him that all of the enemy's children still want. Let him minister to the sick to remind him that the enemy's children still despair. Let him do all these things selflessly, a shining paragon of virtue, so others may look upon him and marvel at his deeds. When he is asked why he performs these things what shall he tell them? "It is God's will"? No, I say. He should reply that he does them from the love within his own heart, and should he be pressed only then will he reveal that it is God's love that shines through him. Let him lead by example, dear Wormwood, and not by decree or doctrine, for humans are foolish and prefer the words of a hypocrite over the actions of a saint. I tell you that the patient should not pass judgement, or if he must, he should not condemn, but offer forgiveness. For this way the patient will be led most astray, by showing grace instead of wrath those around him will be free to sin again, but also take care that the patient not be weak to those who sin against him. Model the patients behavior to mimic the enemy, justice tempered with mercy, so sins of actions are stopped and sins of the heart may heal. Should the patient face danger give him courage, should the patient face adversity give him perseverance, and above all never let him forget the love of the enemy, so that upon his road to damnation he is given some measure of comfort. Most affectionately yours, Uncle Screwtape

Firstly it is important that the patient become involved within his church, let him see that even the most faithful doubt, even the most chaste are tempted, and even the holiest among them sin. You must weed ideas within him that this is acceptable. Remind him that he is naught but a flawed human and without the grace of god he is doomed to perish. Secondly is his works. Encourage the patient at all turns to minister. Let him minister to the poor, to remind him that all of the enemy's children still want. Let him minister to the sick to remind him that the enemy's children still despair. Let him do all these things selflessly, a shining paragon of virtue, so others may look upon him and marvel at his deeds. When he is asked why he performs these things what shall he tell them? "It is God's will"? No, I say. He should reply that he does them from the love within his own heart, and should he be pressed only then will he reveal that it is God's love that shines through him. Let him lead by example, dear Wormwood, and not by decree or doctrine, for humans are foolish and prefer the words of a hypocrite over the actions of a saint. I tell you that the patient should not pass judgement, or if he must, he should not condemn, but offer forgiveness. For this way the patient will be led most astray, by showing grace instead of wrath those around him will be free to sin again, but also take care that the patient not be weak to those who sin against him. Model the patients behavior to mimic the enemy, justice tempered with mercy, so sins of actions are stopped and sins of the heart may heal. Should the patient face danger give him courage, should the patient face adversity give him perseverance, and above all never let him forget the love of the enemy, so that upon his road to damnation he is given some measure of comfort. Most affectionately yours, Uncle Screwtape
