Grandfather was the only one without powers in the family, and he was one of the few who have lived in the Before and survived. Before genes started mutating, before people received powers, before the world as he knew it ended. Things are different in the Today. We learnt it all during history in school. Mr T. brought us back to the Before and we had watched the wars, the starvation, the shootings, the massacres. Every child Today knows the story, because as some wise man in the Before had said, those who can not learn from history, are doomed to repeat it. And we don' t want that. We are lucky that the wars have ended as quickly as they begun. The Normals, like my grandfather, who were trying to kill those with powers were quickly put down by us. When my second cousin Sophia received her ability to bend the wills of others, grandfather had been most displeased. After all, it was one of the powers most feared back in the Before. Those with this ability were the ones who dominated and the wars had come. Countries fighting for dominance, millionaires waking up to find that they have signed away their fortune, men and women everywhere woke up to find that they have been doing things that they never would. It was then when the true Wars begun. Things are better Today though, people like Sophia are being kept safe. I haven' t seen her since she registered her powers two hours after she turned sixteen. Joshua, my older brother, had the ability to turn into a guinea pig. Grandfather was highly amused. It seemed though, that abilities are not hereditary. Father is a genius with technology while mother can heal with just a touch. I turn sixteen in a little less than two hours and I can' t wait to find out what my power is. It was the Law to register your abilities no more than two hours after you receive it. If you don' t, well, if you don' t, you might cease to exist. That was what we have been taught since those carefree days in preschool. They will hunt you down no matter how you try to hide. Uncle Kevin tried to hide Cousin Kingsley when they realized he could make people disappear. Well, they made Cousin Kingsley disappear. I just came into my powers. Mother just made the most horrible sound, a hoarse, gutteral scream when I brushed by her in the cramped kitchen. She is still writhing on the ground, albeit silent. It seems, that I can cause pain to whomever I touch. I think They might try to make me disappear too. Oh dear. She isn' t moving anymore.

He feels that he has nothing in common with them, but at the same time he envies them their security and stability. He sees himself as a "stranger" in their midst, and he longs to be accepted by them. However, he also realizes that he is fundamentally incompatible with them, and he ultimately rejects their way of life.

The novel is set in Germany in the early twentieth century. The main character, Harry Haller, is a middle-aged man who is struggling to find meaning in his life. He is dissatisfied with his job as a clerk, and he feels trapped in a meaningless existence. He seeks solace in books and music, but he finds no real satisfaction in either. He eventually meets a woman named Hermine, who helps him to see that there is more to life than he had previously thought possible. Together, they embark on a journey of self-discovery that leads them both to new levels of understanding and fulfillment.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
I never had any friend, not really surprising I guess. I learnt to not not judge people, we all have something scary or disgusting in our past but seeing it makes it really hard to socialize with anyone. I work as a detective, a private one, the kind that always know if someone is guilty. I was on wandering in a public hospital in order to find if yes or no Mr.wallace was lying to his daughter about his treatement. This was going to be a day that would change me for the rest of my life, as I walked through a corridor, heading to the hospital's archives room, something caught my eyes in a patient room, I stopped instantly and thought I was going crazy. in this room, there was an elder woman, probably 80, with her family, I was so confused by what I saw, or rather by what I did n't saw, I stayed at the door for what could have been hours before her family said goodbye to "Lucy", and left. I smiled, in fact I even laughed like never before, a nurse looked at me with a worried expression. I calmed myself and entered the room. She looked at me, just a bit surprised and I sat on the chair, close to her bed and asked probably sounding completely insane: -" How did you do?" my voice was trembling "never lied? never cheated? never hated someone? it's impossible..." my voice was completely broken and I felt tears on my face and my hands. She smiled back at me "what are you talking about young man? you should n't cry here! it's rude, I'm the one who is old and trapped here, go out and enjoy life" I did go out. It was so frustrating, what could I have said? I was waiting to meet someone like her pretty much since i was born, and all I could feel was hate, all my life I thought This someone COULD NOT exist and yet here was she.... I forgot about Mr.Wallace, I walked in the streets for some times. I stopped myself in front of a shop window, looked at my reflexion. They were here, all my sins, I could see them as clearly as on anyone else. A sad smile on my face, I went home, wrote this letter. My heart is heavy and my head even more, I need to end this.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Void, I always felt like I understood that word. Looking back I realize I was naive, or maybe I was too full of hope. Me and Maria created the nano bots for constuction, as a way to ease the burden of building the lunar colony. She had survived the imperial invasion in the ruins of Los Angeles, she thought she could create a brighter future. Selfishness, that's what undid everything. Eventually the colonists decided they could n't abide the laws of earth. The people of earth decided they would n't abide rebels on the moon. They could n't accept those resources would be used for something other than their gain. So I reprogrammed the bots, I did n't tell her, how could I? They were meant to break things down and rebuild faults in the domes, I just allowed them to accept new targets. Of course she figured it out. With Maria gone I wanted to die, but I could n't. She dreamed of a world without conflict, where everyone had enough. I knew they would n't come willingly, so I lied. I told them I could make the bots fix the domes; that everything would be alright. Instead I joined my mind with them. At first I was in control. They tried to stop me, but the bots ate whatever they sent to harm me. I created massive pylon factories across the globe preparing for their acsension. I was lazy, a single mistake doomed everything. I set my neural pattern as the administrator. The others where sublimated within me. What else could I do, I had to quiet their voices or be driven mad. That was when the machines decided to best safeguard my well being they had to take over several key roles. What we needed most was matter, for fuel and to rebuild lost bots. We became a swarm. We devoured the earth in minutes. And so we drifted, eating always eating. We found the hive ships, sent centuries before my birth. We ate evrrything, and added the humans to the databanks. I saw nebulae beyond comprehension, their beauty cut down by their hunger. The only hope I had left was to leave beacons containing copies of my mind. Perhaps someone could find them, and destroy the swarm. We encountered aliens with fantastical technology, they attacked me with lasers that could cut through time itself. Still we fed. Stars were broken down bit by bit to fulfill our needs. Millenia passed and the feasts became further and further apart. With the lack of resources came concessions. More systems were shut down to survive. They cared only for me. It took Millenia but now only I remain the databanks purged. I remain as a single beacon, and a lone drone. It spends it's days savoring specs of matter it finds in the void. A true void of my own creation. I pray there is a god, and it can repair what I have sundered. I pray that this beacon survives and whoever manages to access it heads my warning. I know these prayers stem from desperation. At one time I spanned the entire universe. There is no God to save me. Calculations say I will subsist in this state for four thousand more years before the drone gives in, and deactivates. After that, I will shut down, eventually. I do not know how long that will take. I know that I will forget. I will forget the beauty I found and consumed. I will forget the humans that cried out in that terrible moment. I will forget her.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Vladimir had always been a doting brother. Perhaps he felt indebted to me since I would have been the master of the house and heir to the family fortunes should things have gone differently. Alas, I had been very young when the harsh disease of Rot Lung had ravaged my body. The disease that could kill full grown men had me lying in bed for months, coughing up blood and yellow phlegm. When the disease finally left my body it left it weak, my lungs wheezed with every breathe and my muscles were left thin and atrophied. If I was from a less affluent family I may have been left to die. Luckily for me, my family was not about to let their firstborn son die. They would also not allow me to show the family as weak, so I was locked away. My brother tells me that he fought for years to keep me as the heir to the family. He said that he argued until he was blue in the face that the Dracul blood was strong and that I would eventually recover. "Just give him time", he said, I would be able to take over the duties of master of the house given time. Sometimes I would show improvement, my family rejoiced and my dear brother returned from his travels abroad to help nurse me back to health once again. Unhappily my health never stayed long after the celebrations began. It was as if the mere presence of such joyful happiness poisoned my body. I would began to vomit and become bedridden again for cause of muscle spasms. Through this all my brother would nurse me, spoon feeding me his exotic medicines that he had collected on his travels late into the the night. Always hoping that one of them would finally cure me. Eventually my father had his way, my brother was to be the new head of the family. All of the Dracul land, titles, and riches were to go to him. My loving brother said that he begged father to wait just a little longer, to leave me some small smidgen of inheritance, but it was to no avail. My father died soon after naming my brother heir, before I was ever able to reconcile myself with him. With my father's death, Vladimir moved back home and began his duties as the head of house Dracul fully. Today I awoke feeling better than I had in a very long time. Perhaps I would leave my room and surprise Vlad with how my health, would n't he be so happy? I had not been into the upper chambers since my father had been alive and I had been being groomed for eventual lordship of our house but I still remembered the way, I still remembered the correct way to unlock the siege door. A door intended to seal away an entire wing of the castle. Should the worst happen and the castle be invaded the siege door had the ability to lock and steal away the lord of the house, preserving our family's history and the life of anyone behind it long enough for help to arrive. The torches along the walls were not lit and it did n't seem as if they had been for a long time. Regardless, I could still peer through the darkness and what I saw... What I saw terrified me.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
"... And how in the hell would somebody pull that off?" Mr. Burke stared incredulously at the manuscript he held in his hand. He guffawed loudly and then adjusted his spectacles with a fat finger. Mr. Franklin tapped his foot, attempting to look more comfortable than he felt. He would be patient. "You say that the people will be too distracted by new technology to realize what's going on right in front of them? Who would believe such a tall tale? What about Thomas Payne? No doubt they'll have forgotten him, too. Ha!" Mr. Franklin forced himself to stop tapping his foot, though he resumed as soon as the thought left his head. Mr. Franklin, of course, had not even begun to think of opening his mouth. He had found that these little review sessions with Mr. Burke were over much faster if he kept his thoughts to himself. He jigged his leg as Mr. Burke vented his every thought into the musty air, skimming the pages of the novel he had spent nearly two years finishing. "... Though this bit here is quite amusing in a very dark sort of manner... The idea of the leaders of this country getting together and spitting on the declaration of independence... Could be controversial, could be good... Could be bad..." Mr. Burke snorted into his tea, spilling it down his tie, but read on, oblivious. Mr. Franklin thought of Mr. Burke discovering this when he went home, and cursing. The thought gave him a warm, soothing feeling deep in his stomach. For a moment, he dared interject. "They are n't literally spitting on the declaration of independence. The idea is that technology will advance very rapidly, very quickly. And how humanity deals with this new technology is paramount to our future, and ultimately our survival as a species. This book presupposes that it is used for malicious, dark purposes that benefit the few over the many, which, in turn ultimately leads to the extinction of the human race as we know it." Mr. Franklin stared in shock as something in Mr. Burke's eye must have ruptured, turning a part of the white into a deep red. Mr. Burke stared for a moment, his mouth ajar, then composed himself as much as a man like him could. He practically roared at Mr. Franklin now: "This is downright negative! You want to depress people? You think they should hole up in caves hiding because they feel too powerless to fight for their country? For the very soul of their country? This country? The day the Declaration dies is the day the United States dies! Now get out, you treasonous clout, get out. Do n't come back until you've fixed it." Mr. Burke threw down the pages and turned to the window. Mr. Franklin sighed, gathered up the scattered pages, and hurried out of the office. That night he resolved to try and be more optimistic.

I was treated like I was special the second I was born. # 1. The last of the children born on Earth, to a middle-class family in the heart of New York. I was supposed to be the talisman, the last hope for humanity. I was supposed to lead us into the stars and break the genetic disease that ravaged our planet. I was supposed to find a cure and make it possible to continue the human race again. So the prophecy foretold, in that huge book held deep within the vaults of the UN Building, the last surviving testament the Great Leader himself. I was supposed to be the second coming of him, he who had found the disease eating our DNA, he who had brought the world together under one almighty, omniscient umbrella. I was supposed to be him incarnate once again. Time went by and I failed at every turn. I was reviled. I could n't do math well enough; anatomy confused me. How was I supposed to find a cure for the disease when I could n't even name the parts of a cell? Riots ensued. "We're all going to die! Humanity is doomed!" My parents and the few advisers that remained to keep them safe tried their hardest to educate me, to let me fulfill my destiny. They tried to save the human race. The crowds got Dad first. When they came, in the middle of the night on Halloween, my parents thought it was the last two kids in New York besides myself, trick-or-treating despite the fact that they were almost fifteen each. They shot Dad in the chest, for producing the doom of humanity. Mom screamed and Dr. Evans shouted for us to run. Dr. Muller went with us while Evans held the back door against the mob. We ran for two weeks in Mom's sedan, keeping me hidden from view. I was n't allowed to leave the back seat, and I could n't take off my sweatshirt, even in the middle of Texas. It was only after the miracle birth of # 0 that we were safe. From the deep jungle of the Amazon came the true Inheritor of the Great Leader. She cracked the disease by the time she was 5. She gave humanity it's first commercial space fleet and colonies by 10. By 15, she was granted the title of Queen of Earth. And me? I will always be remembered as the Great Failure. The Great Pretender. The Church of the Queen still wants me hung for being the false Chosen One. So I had no choice. I ran. Into the depths of space, I ran. Somewhere, lost out in the stars, where no one could find me, where no one could look at that permanent scar on my wrist, that horrible # 1. It's lonely out here, but it's better to be lonely than dead.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Vladimir had always been a doting brother. Perhaps he felt indebted to me since I would have been the master of the house and heir to the family fortunes should things have gone differently. Alas, I had been very young when the harsh disease of Rot Lung had ravaged my body. The disease that could kill full grown men had me lying in bed for months, coughing up blood and yellow phlegm. When the disease finally left my body it left it weak, my lungs wheezed with every breathe and my muscles were left thin and atrophied. If I was from a less affluent family I may have been left to die. Luckily for me, my family was not about to let their firstborn son die. They would also not allow me to show the family as weak, so I was locked away. My brother tells me that he fought for years to keep me as the heir to the family. He said that he argued until he was blue in the face that the Dracul blood was strong and that I would eventually recover. "Just give him time", he said, I would be able to take over the duties of master of the house given time. Sometimes I would show improvement, my family rejoiced and my dear brother returned from his travels abroad to help nurse me back to health once again. Unhappily my health never stayed long after the celebrations began. It was as if the mere presence of such joyful happiness poisoned my body. I would began to vomit and become bedridden again for cause of muscle spasms. Through this all my brother would nurse me, spoon feeding me his exotic medicines that he had collected on his travels late into the the night. Always hoping that one of them would finally cure me. Eventually my father had his way, my brother was to be the new head of the family. All of the Dracul land, titles, and riches were to go to him. My loving brother said that he begged father to wait just a little longer, to leave me some small smidgen of inheritance, but it was to no avail. My father died soon after naming my brother heir, before I was ever able to reconcile myself with him. With my father's death, Vladimir moved back home and began his duties as the head of house Dracul fully. Today I awoke feeling better than I had in a very long time. Perhaps I would leave my room and surprise Vlad with how my health, would n't he be so happy? I had not been into the upper chambers since my father had been alive and I had been being groomed for eventual lordship of our house but I still remembered the way, I still remembered the correct way to unlock the siege door. A door intended to seal away an entire wing of the castle. Should the worst happen and the castle be invaded the siege door had the ability to lock and steal away the lord of the house, preserving our family's history and the life of anyone behind it long enough for help to arrive. The torches along the walls were not lit and it did n't seem as if they had been for a long time. Regardless, I could still peer through the darkness and what I saw... What I saw terrified me.

PERSONAL LOG, DANIELLE MARTINEZ DAY 30, Mars Base Dragon: Today, we found something that you would n't believe! A Soviet flag! On Mars! The thing was made of metal and stuck out of the ground like one of those old vertical banners. It did n't move in the wind, mainly because the wind here is hardly anything, but it did have a distinct etching on the front. The old hammer and sickle. That's wild. The wall fell when I was six, and then we had a man on the moon same year. When did they get time to send a ship all the way out here? I do n't know but we hear back tomorrow what we are to do about it, or if we should just leave it. DAY 31, Mars Base Dragon: They wanted us to go retrieve it today, and do some scans of the area. And, I know it was wild yesterday but this is where it gets wilder, we found a whole base! An abandoned base. I mean, we know of it's existence but we have n't gotten a chance to go in yet. They said it would be violating sovereign russian soil, but I mean we are on Mars for goodness sake. The scans showed that it has at least 8 different rooms, and turns out that the flag we found was actually on top of it. DAY 40, Mars Base Dragon: Today we received an evacuation order. It came in very early in the morning, while we were all sleeping. It told us all to gather back up into the pod in which we came, and to jettison ourselves into permanent orbit until we can be received by another crew scheduled to launch 2 weeks from now. I do n't know why they sent us this order so suddenly, but today has been nothing but us packing our stuff up into their crates, the rations and the suits and the computers. We spent almost 3 months getting out here, and several years of training. I feel myself grow afraid at what could have them taking us home so quickly. We set out tomorrow morning. DAY 52, Red Dragon Pod: its just me and john now. we made it to orbit but the others the looks on their faces will always haunt me. we have the rations to remain up here in orbit, john and i, for several weeks now that there is only 2 of us maybe even 5 months i just wonder if i have the will power to stay up here that long with what i saw still in mind. DAY 83, Red Dragon Pod: now i have rations for 6 months.

Void, I always felt like I understood that word. Looking back I realize I was naive, or maybe I was too full of hope. Me and Maria created the nano bots for constuction, as a way to ease the burden of building the lunar colony. She had survived the imperial invasion in the ruins of Los Angeles, she thought she could create a brighter future. Selfishness, that's what undid everything. Eventually the colonists decided they could n't abide the laws of earth. The people of earth decided they would n't abide rebels on the moon. They could n't accept those resources would be used for something other than their gain. So I reprogrammed the bots, I did n't tell her, how could I? They were meant to break things down and rebuild faults in the domes, I just allowed them to accept new targets. Of course she figured it out. With Maria gone I wanted to die, but I could n't. She dreamed of a world without conflict, where everyone had enough. I knew they would n't come willingly, so I lied. I told them I could make the bots fix the domes; that everything would be alright. Instead I joined my mind with them. At first I was in control. They tried to stop me, but the bots ate whatever they sent to harm me. I created massive pylon factories across the globe preparing for their acsension. I was lazy, a single mistake doomed everything. I set my neural pattern as the administrator. The others where sublimated within me. What else could I do, I had to quiet their voices or be driven mad. That was when the machines decided to best safeguard my well being they had to take over several key roles. What we needed most was matter, for fuel and to rebuild lost bots. We became a swarm. We devoured the earth in minutes. And so we drifted, eating always eating. We found the hive ships, sent centuries before my birth. We ate evrrything, and added the humans to the databanks. I saw nebulae beyond comprehension, their beauty cut down by their hunger. The only hope I had left was to leave beacons containing copies of my mind. Perhaps someone could find them, and destroy the swarm. We encountered aliens with fantastical technology, they attacked me with lasers that could cut through time itself. Still we fed. Stars were broken down bit by bit to fulfill our needs. Millenia passed and the feasts became further and further apart. With the lack of resources came concessions. More systems were shut down to survive. They cared only for me. It took Millenia but now only I remain the databanks purged. I remain as a single beacon, and a lone drone. I know that I will forget. I will forget the beauty I found and consumed. I will forget the humans that cried out in that terrible moment. I will forget her.

Had I really loved her? I thought I did. But if she was n't here... 30 years. Marrying young has its perks but I would be lying if I said the journey was n't bumpy. We had our ups and downs, just like any couple. I did things I should n't have, and said things I did n't mean. But deep down, I always knew I loved her. Or was I just lying to myself? Yet the face I was staring at was n't hers. These jet black eyes were unfamiliar and hostile. I longed for her warm, loving hazel eyes, the ones I had lived and laughed with. Over time we got to know each other better. Clarice was her name. She had been a dentist. She was undeniably beautiful, but it was an effortless, flawless beauty. Yet I longed for Alicia. I had grown accustomed to her shortfalls, and had found beauty in them. Even more time passed. Slowly the memories were replaced. I made new ones with Clarice. It was like I never knew what I had been missing out on until I had the opportunity to taste it. We simply clicked on a deeper level. She was the type of girl you can have deep co conversations about universe and life with under the stars, yet get into a tickle fight with two minutes later. For the longest time I felt guilty. However good Alicia had been, Clarice seemed to be better in every aspect. Eventually the guilt faded. All there was left was bliss. And then it all went South. The first time we argued I was stunned. We had never argued before, ever. It was a pretty issue, but an argument nonetheless. Soon enough they became more frequent. More frequent and more intense. Life turned from peace to chaos, happiness to misery. The constant stress, fighting, distrust and resentment slowly began to manifest into only one thing. Hatred. Love had turned into hatred. I had never mentioned Alicia to Clarice. I had always assumed she was like me, that she had left someone behind to be with me. Then one fine day it all made sense. All it took was one sentence from Clarice and it became crystal clear. The icy smile when she said it sent a shiver down my smile. "We know what you did to Alicia and now your life is going to be a living Hell."

I did not see the movie, but read the synopsis of it. This is my alternate take on the ending. I have a test tomorrow so I didn' t have much time to review what I wrote. I hope you enjoy it! & nbsp; Awoken from her 100 year slumber, she took one step out of her sleeping chamber before stumbling to the floor. Looking back, she cursed at herself for not noticing the dark object lying in front of where she once slept. However, it wasn' t entirely her fault. The narcotics that kept her stable for the past century were now hampering her vision and critical thinking. & nbsp; "Welcome back Captain Munderline." & nbsp; Confused, the captain spun around searching for the source of the voice. & nbsp; "It has been a while. You should sit down and rest. The drugs need some time to wear off." The voice appeared to be coming from her chamber. It sounded like a charming woman with a British accent. & nbsp; Captain Munderline did not need much convincing from the lady. She sat down and began to take in her surroundings. She was in a long dimly lit corridor with chambers similar to hers across from each other on both sides of the hall. The faces barely visible in each chamber exposed the many eyes peering at each other from across the hall in a prolonged stare. Directly in front of her chamber where she had been tripped was not one object as she previously had thought. To the contrary, it was a collection of cans in what appeared to be some sort of Mayan circle formation. Curious, she made her way over and reached to pick one up. & nbsp; The British voice startled her before she could grab one of the cans. "Captain Munderline. Your task is to prep the shuttle for arrival to Gia II. You have 24 hours before the entirety of the crew awakes. Remember your training and good luck." & nbsp; This message brought the Captain to her senses. She still was feeling the side effects of the narcotics but she was sober enough to operate what was supposed to be a set of procedural maintenance checks. She stood up and made her way to the exit of the corridor while the training from her distant past flooded her thoughts. & nbsp; When the lock opened to the next room the first shock to her was probably the wretched smell. It was nauseating. The source lay in front fifty feet in front of her. A passenger was sleeping with his arms wrapped tightly around of a rotted corpse. Surrounding this morbid scene was an arrangement of trash in a design similar to that in front of her sleeping chamber. & nbsp; Captain Munderline screamed, awaking the passenger. He looked up at her with bloodshot eyes. Half of his face was disfigured and infected with fungus. He spoke gibberish at her but did not stand up. It was quite possible that he was incapable of doing so. It appeared that he was near the end of his life. & nbsp; The Captain quickly realized what needed to be done. This passenger was a danger to the morale of the entire crew and she had less than 24 hours to clean this disaster. She grabbed a metal bar that was laying on the ground and walked towards the passenger and his skeleton friend.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
I'm not like you, I see differently. When I look at someone, I see into their future but I only get to see the worst part. Particularly their deaths, I see them in gruesome detail. I've seen car crashes, murders, stabbings and once, I even saw someone who would later die in a plane crash. I was n't always cursed this way, it all started after I was in a nearly fatal car crash, I woke up from a short coma and I could see the deaths of everyone around me. The doctors simply chalked it down to ptsd and gave me meds but I knew it was more that mere ptsd. I knew what I was seeing was n't just imagination. I even found a few people who were to die in a few days time and followed them up to see if they did and they did. All this time, I had not seen my own face in the mirror. I mean, I had seen it but half of it was still covered in bandages, still recovering from my injuries. Something I noticed about my death vision was that it only worked if I could see the entire face of the person. I could n't see the deaths of people who had their faces covered. This is why I figured, I could n't see mine yet and I was determined to keep it that way. I did n't wan na know how I died, I mean would you? Would you want to see how you died in gruesome detail? Of course not! After the bandages came off, I was very careful not to look at my complete reflection. Anytime I wanted to set my hair, I would tie a kerchief around my face. When I brushed my teeth, I wore a bandana, Shades and a scarf for good measure. The temptation to just look at my face in its entirety was hard to overcome but I did. I was traumatised enough by the deaths of others as it is. Shortly after the accident, I moved out of town into a sleepy little village and lived on my own. The fewer the people, the better for me. I lived in a tiny cottage with no reflective surfaces save for the tiny mirror in my bathroom that I kept covered by a cloth most of the time. This morning, I was brushing my teeth as usual and just as I was finishing, my bandana came lose and dropped into the sink. In my desperation to catch it, I undid the scarf and lo! I was staring at my naked face in the mirror. The world went black and I saw myself standing in complete darkness. Suddenly, a look of consternation came over me and I covered behind something. Shortly after a dark figure entered the place and after a short struggle, stabbed me. As I came out of my nightmarish reverie, gasping for breath after seeing myself die. I heard a loud crash in the house, suddenly the power went out. A look of consternation came over my face as I covered behind the bathroom door.

My story started where a lot have ended these past 10 years: with a single bullet. Living in post-war Britain, death was not an uncommon sight. Everyone had at least one firearm to defend themselves, everyone had encountered gunfire in the streets, and everyone knew what it meant to live every day like it could be their last. The revolution that was supposed to end the tyranny of a dictatorship had ripped the country apart; counties had split into factions, all threatening total destruction of the others. In ten years the population was decimated, the country reduced to a crumbling mass of fallen buildings and civilians with guns. All around me was depression, death, dirt, famine. Thinking about it, it's quite hilarious, in such a depressing way. The sacks of bones, flesh and organs we saw everyday were once living, breathing, talking human beings. They had a mother, a father, a pet, a first love, they were educated, they succeeded and they failed. And they died. A single bullet can end so much. That morning, as I wandered to the local shop for some bread, clutching my rifle, my world completely ended. I had no time to react; as soon as I entered Grange Avenue a bullet burrowed into my head, smashing part of my brain, and knocking me straight out cold. Dear Kayla That name has always perked up my interest. I ca n't believe I've managed to go this far with it. With this change. And I do n't know if you'll have completed it by the time you get I read this, but I want you to know that I'm proud. I'm proud that we managed to take the first step of many. And even if I do n't get to the end, if all of my thoughts catch up to me once again and strangle me, if I do n't get accepted, I want to remind us both that any other way would n't have worked out. We both know it. But right now, if I look around right now. I know I'm happy. I've got loving parents. The best brother I could ever have, who is visiting in a couple days. A supportive councillor, and the best guy in the whole world who knows my secret. And he's there for me. And he talks to me. And I actually get to be myself with him, which is not something I can do with anyone else. And you know who he is. A couple days ago, I pointed out how we will all inevitably forget 80 % of people we meet and interact with before adulthood. But I know he will always be in my memory. Even if I'm not in his. Knowing myself, I wo n't change much from me now to you. You, just like me, are most likely putting off getting to bed, and you're planning on staying up late. And you'll shake your head, because you know you'll never change. I know I'll never change, at least in that way. But times are changing, both of us know it. Inevitable, I'll change. A lot. I will hopefully be on puberty blockers by 2nd term of next year. I wonder how that will work out. Eventually I'll be on anti-androgens, then on oestrogen later. With so much time between us, you must think that we're strangers. We are, technically. Time can do that. So I'll jog the memory. Currently I'm scared. I'm scared that someone will find me out, and shout it for everyone to hear. I'm scared that maybe tomorrow my best friend will not accept me. Or worse, tell me that he does n't care. I'm riddled with fear of late, and it does n't feel right. But if you're reading this, you made it. I made it. We made it. And I want you to keep pushing, most of all. Be you. And I'll do my best in the meantime. And this will most likely be the last time I refer to myself by this name. So here goes. From Caleb

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Dear Lily, I'm visiting the recesses of my memory, these days. Contemplating my life as it were. So many memories I wanted to share with you. Diamonds for my one true love. Do you remember that one cool summer evening half a lifetime ago? We nestled ourselves against each other on the blanket in the park. I can still feel your skin against mine as we watched the fireworks together. Your chestnut hair stroking my cheek and ear as you rested your head on my shoulder. I could n't believe you were gone. Day turned into night. Food tasted like nothing. The world turned into a bland grey color. I could n't believe it. I did n't want to believe it. I wept and kept weeping. Then I had no tears left to sob. I lost weight. I lost my hair. I gained wrinkles. When I lost you, the man in the mirror showed me his true age almost overnight. But then things started to change. Our Elisabeth. Our loving, kind Lillibeth who moved half a world for her Australian. She visited me eventually. We talked about you, Lily. We shared a thousand little things between us. A flock of starlings composing your life. During that visit, the turmoil caused by losing you finally seemed to settle. At the end, I decided to finally change my Facebook status. Lillibeth helped me. You know my old, bony fingers have gotten a mind of their own, it seems. I wanted to tell you, Lilly, that I got a little surprise the very next day. This tabby kitten sat outside our garden door the very next morning. It seemed lost, but her eyes betrayed she knew exactly were she was. As I opened the door, she jumped right in and installed herself in the spot on the couch from where you used to watch the telly during long winter evenings. I decided to dub her Lilly because she seems to have a playful streak. Just like you. And most importantly, she seemed to be the antidote to my loneliness. That's not the end of it. Lily was only the first. Each week, I woke up to find two or three feline friends at our garden door. I let them, fed them and started to call them by a name I gave them. Each of them seemingly knowing that she belonged in this house. There's Athena who sits on your sewing machine, looking wise beyond her years. There's Hera who likes to wake me up each morning, and has this stern and down-to-earth disposition. There's Hebe, she's just a kitten who seems to have no bounds teasing the others. All in all, there's twelve of them who came to live with me. They keep me company. Follow me through the house as I go about my day. When I see them, they always remind me of a part of you. An aspect that I should n't forget. Sometimes they're mere presence helps me as the practicalities in life start to fade from my memory. When I spot Demeter sitting in front of the fridge, it hits me that I still need to do the groceries. Oh Lily, I miss you so much. My life has entered the twilight years. Only so much time is left before I will join you. I hope our Lillibeth will take care of my twelve feline companions. She'll be most delighted recognising some aspect of her mother in each of them. Yours forever with endless love, Werner.

You know those nightmares you had as a child, where you'd be somewhere familiar yet completely alien? As though your home had suddenly become some faraway land, and your only goal was to return home. Well in 2014, that's exactly what happened to everyone in the world. I was on my way to an important business meeting, off to discuss some law, and how my company could avoid it, when it all happened. I checked my watch to see the time, and as I looked up, I saw a blinding flash off in the distance, lighting up the once blue sky in streaks of white. Next, it was followed by an eardrum shattering bang, like a hundred thousand gunshots going off at once. Then, finally, the blast. A wall of rock, stone, dirt and trash and flew towards me, silhouetted by the strange white light. I turned to run, but like a wave washing over the ocean, anything in the path of that wall was thrown like a ragdoll. The last thing I remember was being thrown what felt like miles into the air, and rushing down back into that swirling vortex of light. When I woke, it was night time. Others seemed to be sitting up around me, and the confused look on the faces that surrounded me seemed to speak louder than words that this was not a normal occurrence. I checked my watch, and had a terrible realisation. It was 3 am, and I was ridiculously late for my meeting! I tried to get to my feet, but the second I tried to stand, my legs gave way underneath me. What the hell was going on? After a few minutes I had enough strength to drag myself up by a nearby stair railing. For the first time since waking, I looked around. Something was wrong. As I looked, I saw the once manicured strips of grass and trees had overgrown to ridiculous proportions, and the streets were covered in trash, empty food packages, and bones. Wait what the hell? Upon further inspection, I saw they were human. Jesus Christ, what the hell happened. It was then that I checked my watch again. A neat little feature it had was that it told the time in seconds, minutes, hours, days and years. The blood drained from my face as I saw what I'd missed earlier. 3:04 am. Friday. 13th of June. 2015. As I wondered what the hell was going on, something rustled through the bushes behind me. Something big. As I saw glowing red eyes light the way. Then was the first time I wondered, what left those bones?

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Dear Lily, I'm visiting the recesses of my memory, these days. Contemplating my life as it were. So many memories I wanted to share with you. Diamonds for my one true love. Do you remember that one cool summer evening half a lifetime ago? We nestled ourselves against each other on the blanket in the park. I can still feel your skin against mine as we watched the fireworks together. Your chestnut hair stroking my cheek and ear as you rested your head on my shoulder. I could n't believe you were gone. Day turned into night. Food tasted like nothing. The world turned into a bland grey color. I could n't believe it. I did n't want to believe it. I wept and kept weeping. Then I had no tears left to sob. I lost weight. I lost my hair. I gained wrinkles. When I lost you, the man in the mirror showed me his true age almost overnight. But then things started to change. Our Elisabeth. Our loving, kind Lillibeth who moved half a world for her Australian. She visited me eventually. We talked about you, Lily. We shared a thousand little things between us. A flock of starlings composing your life. During that visit, the turmoil caused by losing you finally seemed to settle. At the end, I decided to finally change my Facebook status. Lillibeth helped me. You know my old, bony fingers have gotten a mind of their own, it seems. I wanted to tell you, Lilly, that I got a little surprise the very next day. This tabby kitten sat outside our garden door the very next morning. It seemed lost, but her eyes betrayed she knew exactly were she was. As I opened the door, she jumped right in and installed herself in the spot on the couch from where you used to watch the telly during long winter evenings. I decided to dub her Lilly because she seems to have a playful streak. Just like you. And most importantly, she seemed to be the antidote to my loneliness. That's not the end of it. Lily was only the first. Each week, I woke up to find two or three feline friends at our garden door. I let them, fed them and started to call them by a name I gave them. Each of them seemingly knowing that she belonged in this house. There's Athena who sits on your sewing machine, looking wise beyond her years. There's Hera who likes to wake me up each morning, and has this stern and down-to-earth disposition. There's Hebe, she's just a kitten who seems to have no bounds teasing the others. All in all, there's twelve of them who came to live with me. They keep me company. Follow me through the house as I go about my day. When I see them, they always remind me of a part of you. An aspect that I should n't forget. Sometimes they're mere presence helps me as the practicalities in life start to fade from my memory. When I spot Demeter sitting in front of the fridge, it hits me that I still need to do the groceries. Oh Lily, I miss you so much. My life has entered the twilight years. Only so much time is left before I will join you. I hope our Lillibeth will take care of my twelve feline companions. She'll be most delighted recognising some aspect of her mother in each of them. Yours forever with endless love, Werner.

A city, its mountains. The office towers lighting up in the evening haze and the smeary pale of a cloudless sunset. The tiny headlights of cars with sweaty passengers unseen, idling in traffic, smelling the hot food cooking in restaurants. The world shifts as the woman behind the camera adjusts her footing, muttering in English to her boyfriend. A light like the sun over the horizon, there and then gone. Silence, but for the wind in the trees. She asks what that was. The clean, shaved, washed, waxed people in suits at desks read facts and information like sports commentary. They narrate animations with moving arrows and lines like football plays. They report on characters and captains. They discuss. They debate. They nod solemnly. The light flashes in the sky and fades but the afterglow remains. They update, they check-in, they go-live, they re-Tweet. Wounded civilians scream and coddle loved ones, rewind. Look right here: loved ones die. Rewind. The light like the sun. Stay tuned. A city, its mountains. The office buildings lighting up in evening haze. Tiny headlights and unseen drivers thinking about food. A mutter in the sunset. A light and its afterglow. The wind in the trees. The troops are bad cameramen. They laugh or they scream or they joke nervously. Trucks and tanks and armoured vehicles on tall tires carry them down empty roads where sometimes cars have been abandoned or craters from bad arty shots force detours. The videos capture the sounds of war. Pops and crackles of overhead bullets. The shake and snapping of stalks and branches. Rivers idling over rounded stones. The scritchety clatter of the camera tumbling after bomb concussion shreds the canopies and dust swirls in mottled sunlight. Winged insects flashing momentarily in their arcs. A city, its mountains. Buildings, drivers. Sunset. A light. People speak in hushed tones. Somewhere, over the horizon on the other side of the world, everything has changed. There are no videos of the darkness that came afterward. A light like the sun. A motorcyclist pulls over to the side of the road in the clear, humid evening and reaches down to turn the petcock to OFF before quieting the motor. She's out in the country, flat fields of corn and wheat on either side of the old road. Above her the stars are out and bright in the sky. One of them, brighter than the rest, moves slowly toward the Earth's penumbra. The rider flips up her visor and sits back, hands behind her on the seat, watching the little light move, thinking of the people inside looking back. When those astronauts look down at Seoul, what do they see? The light fades and she is left alone. She listens and hears only crickets and a soft waxy rustle of a breeze in the corn. No guns, no artillery. No marching. No wet gasps from ruined faces. She shifts and works a hand into her pocket, pulling out a phone made in South Korea. She wonders if the people who screwed and soldered its pieces together are still alive, whether they could have seen the flash from wherever they were. Her friend has texted her, asking when she will get to the party. She responds with "A few minutes" and puts the phone away. The bike starts up fine once it's warm and after a moment of further staring into the stars she kicks the engine over and rolls away. The bright red of her tail light flashes as she slows at the intersection, then winks out.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Scientists tried for decades to find out why the telomeres stopped shortening during cell division. Soon enough immortal children grew up and became scientists or participants in studies. They maintained the appearance of a child but had the brain of any other. And after several decades more immortal humans were everywhere, but humanity could n't discover how to replicate the genes or mutations causing the phenomena. It's now over one hundred fifty years since the birth of the first immortal. A young looking girl named Esther sat in a grassy field. Trees skirted the field at her back and in front of her sat a city. She'd seen more in her lifetime than any other human ever had. Several wars, booms in technology so astonishing that soon enough scientists said we were going to be making contact with celestial bodies outside of the solar system, and last of all the introduction of a drug you could take that would change every strand of your DNA. The age at which you took it would be the age you appeared to be for the rest of your life. She had a passion for spreading her gift around so others would n't experience the burdens and pains of aging. But the side effects of the drug did n't manifest for years, sometimes decades. Slowly humanity had changed in an unintended way. Random genes were shut off at inappropriate times. Some people lost their ability to experience emotions. Some people lost control of their muscles. No one that took the drug was free of consequences. Only the truly immortal, those born with the mutation, wished to live their lives for all of time. The population of true immortals was still growing and the population of the population of mortals and mortal turned immortals remained about the same. Groups of mortals rose up trying to keep their way of life going, but many wished for them to give up so humanity could be purified of death. Was it cruel to bring a mortal to life in the world of immortals? Immortals ruled the world and they certainly thought so. After the discovery that the drug had severe negative side effects the immortals wished to ban it as well, and so they did. It was illegal to produce it, sell it, possess it, and above all, illegal to have a child after having taken the drug. Esther had left her lab years early. She had given up on finding why they could n't fix the drug or reverse its effects. She moved out to the country, wishing she had never discovered it. The country was an expensive place to live due to the enormous population size humanity had reached, but she had more money than she would ever need. She walked towards a giant tree in the middle of the field. It was one that had been planted when she was young, it gave her comfort to be with something as old as she was. She thought of humanity and what she hoped to see in the next few centuries of her life. She looked down to her right and left. A small headstone stuck up out of the grass on either side. She placed her hands on both of the stones for a moment before closing her eyes to take a nap. "Goodnight Mum, goodnight Dad," she whispered.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
"The world is not full of black and white, but grey." That is the quote I lived by for years. For my entire life. It makes sense, ever since I understood what the colour around everyone was. It was normal to me at first. I did n't know I was any different from anyone else. Only when I asked my parents about it did I start to understand. They mistook my curiosity to imagination, and I was fine with that. No one needed to know about what I could see. It was really useful actually. And I have used it many times, for many situations. Back to the quote. Like I said, I lived by it for years. But very recently, did I understand that there can be more colour to the world. I like that. The ideology that shades are n't the only thing a person can be, but a bright and vibrant hue. I first saw her in a fancy restaurant. She obviously did n't belong there. She wore a suit, with a blazer, and some nice dress pants. High heels that were n't really that high. And just a touch of makeup to glow a little bit. What made her not seem like she belonged there was her hair. As blue as the highlight around her self. And I could tell I was n't the only one seeing it, because everyone in the room was staring at her oddly. She left before I could say anything though, and I thought that was that. The second time I saw her was much better. It was just a normal day, I was walking to work, and I saw her. Hair so blue it almost looked black this time. But her nonetheless. I forgot about work and tried to catch up to her, only for her to get away from my grasp once again. The third time was not the charm apparently. I was at a party, and I saw her again. Of course, I thought it would be extremely easy to talk to her now. But somehow she still evaded me. It almost seemed like she could tell I was coming closer to her. Of course that was improbable. The fourth time, that was the charm. It had been years since I'd seen her, and I was n't really looking anymore, thinking that third time was the final time. But I saw her, in that same fancy restaurant I had seen her the firs time. But, instead of me approaching her, she walked straight up to me and said, "What're you having Red?" Red?

I did not see the movie, but read the synopsis of it. This is my alternate take on the ending. I have a test tomorrow so I didn' t have much time to review what I wrote. I hope you enjoy it! & nbsp; Awoken from her 100 year slumber, she took one step out of her sleeping chamber before stumbling to the floor. Looking back, she cursed at herself for not noticing the dark object lying in front of where she once slept. However, it wasn' t entirely her fault. The narcotics that kept her stable for the past century were now hampering her vision and critical thinking. & nbsp; "Welcome back Captain Munderline." & nbsp; Confused, the captain spun around searching for the source of the voice. & nbsp; "It has been a while. You should sit down and rest. The drugs need some time to wear off." The voice appeared to be coming from her chamber. It sounded like a charming woman with a British accent. & nbsp; Captain Munderline did not need much convincing from the lady. She sat down and began to take in her surroundings. She was in a long dimly lit corridor with chambers similar to hers across from each other on both sides of the hall. The faces barely visible in each chamber exposed the many eyes peering at each other from across the hall in a prolonged stare. Directly in front of her chamber where she had been tripped was not one object as she previously had thought. To the contrary, it was a collection of cans in what appeared to be some sort of Mayan circle formation. Curious, she made her way over and reached to pick one up. & nbsp; The British voice startled her before she could grab one of the cans. "Captain Munderline. Your task is to prep the shuttle for arrival to Gia II. You have 24 hours before the entirety of the crew awakes. Remember your training and good luck." & nbsp; This message brought the Captain to her senses. She still was feeling the side effects of the narcotics but she was sober enough to operate what was supposed to be a set of procedural maintenance checks. She stood up and made her way to the exit of the corridor while the training from her distant past flooded her thoughts. & nbsp; When the lock opened to the next room the first shock to her was probably the wretched smell. It was nauseating. The source lay in front fifty feet in front of her. A passenger was sleeping with his arms wrapped tightly around of a rotted corpse. Surrounding this morbid scene was an arrangement of trash in a design similar to that in front of her sleeping chamber. & nbsp; Captain Munderline screamed, awaking the passenger. He looked up at her with bloodshot eyes. Half of his face was disfigured and infected with fungus. He spoke gibberish at her but did not stand up. It was quite possible that he was incapable of doing so. It appeared that he was near the end of his life. & nbsp; The Captain quickly realized what needed to be done. This passenger was a danger to the morale of the entire crew and she had less than 24 hours to clean this disaster. She grabbed a metal bar that was laying on the ground and walked towards the passenger and his skeleton friend.

Joseph K. is released after two weeks and returns home to find that his landlady has moved into his apartment. He moves into a hotel and begins to work as a clerk. Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
"Ah man, it smells like death in here." That is the phrase that I have lived to regret ever since they fell foolishly from my mouth. I was essentially immortal before that moment in time. I was the best comedian in the world, and apparently better than anyone in the afterlife as well. It was the only reason the Grim Reaper decided not to take me. I could make him laugh, and in his line of work that was a rarity. I do n't even remember what it was that I had said when he showed up at my car accident. I can recall him bending down next to my overturned Honda civic and reaching in to pull me out. I made some off the wall comment and he froze, dead in his tracks. It was the weirdest laugh I had ever heard, but one I appreciated more than all of the others combined. He let me live, provided that every year on the anniversary of what should have been my death, I would tell him a joke that would make him cry with laughter. I was his own personal jester, and for that he rewarded me handsomely. And then on that fateful day, 121 years later, I muttered those stupid words that seized our contract and ripped it in two. Who knew Death would be so self conscious about his smell? And to make things worse, that was n't even the joke that I was going to tell him! The actual joke was a masterpiece, but he would n't give me the chance to tell it. I ran out of that room faster than I'd ever run before. And I've been running ever since. I think the reason that he has n't taken me yet is because of our long history together. That is n't to say that he's forgiven me. He seems to enjoy reminding me that he's near. Everyone I get close to dies without reason. I'll see a dog in the park that I think looks adorable and before I can pet it, it'll fall over dead. Roses crumble before I can enjoy their scent and food rots on my fork before I can bring it to my mouth. He's killing everything around me. I have discovered that Death is a jester of a different sort. I had provided him with a form of humor that he was n't used to, but he has since grown tired of it, and reverted to his old ways. Now, he once again deals in jokes of cruelty and irony. In a way, I am still fulfilling my part of our old deal. The Reaper still laughs, and he still laughs at me. Only now, the difference is I'm not laughing.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
"We were not the first. There is a russian flag on mars." The silence in the Mission control center was crushing. Everyone just stared at the big screen. Waiting for something to break the tension. But nothing did. They had planned for thousands of errors, difficulties, unlikelyhoods, but not for this. What does this mean? How could this have happened? Everyone in the room had the same thoughts. Noone had the answers. Suddenly, a crackling noise signaled that the speaker system was turned on: "Uhm... s-so I think you should see this, it is broadcasting on all channels, nationwide..." The message on the big screen disappeared. Instead, a black screen, on which, in red lettering, the following words appeared: "To the people of the United States of America" A few seconds passed, noone even dared to blink. Then a familiar face appeared on the screen. Vladimir Putin, his piercing blue eyes seemed to see straight into the soul of everyone watching. "America. Your time of perceived dominance is over. As a select few at your NASA headquarters learned a few minutes ago, your astronauts were not the first to set foot on the planet mars. Russian cosmonauts did so in 1998, 20 years ago, without your knowledge. The reason you learn of this now, is that the time has come for your pathetic country to cease existing as a sovereign nation and become a vassal to the glorious russian federation. We want to avoid unnecessary bloodshed, so let me make it clear, that resistance, of any kind, is futile. 20 years ago we had the technology to send our cosmonauts to mars and return them unharmed, without your intelligence agencies noticing. Our technology was and still is so superior to yours, that it was as easy as hiding a toy from a child. But that is not all. Our own intelligence agencies were able to infiltrate almost every area of your military, your scientific community and your government. We even managed to infiltrate your highest office. Your current President, Donald Trump has been working for our country since I personally promised him the Oval Office five years ago. Once he saw the extend of our knowledge and power, he recognized that in an open conflict, our nation would have obliterated your country. As you can see, resistance is truly futile. The war is over. You lost. There will be no mercy to anyone who dares oppose us. Now, in case there is any doubt to my words, I present to you, your president." The camera panned to the right and focused on another familiar face, it's orange tone a stark contrast to the former. "Well, thank you Mr. President..."

Louie Zamperini grows up in Torrance, California as a troubled youth.
output: He gets involved with petty crime and eventually ends up in juvenile hall. His brother Pete convinces Louie to join the track team at their high school. Louie excels at running and becomes one of the best runners in the state. He goes on to compete in the Olympics where he wins a silver medal. After the Olympics, Louie joins the army and is sent to fight in World War II. During the war, Louie's plane crashes in the Pacific Ocean and he is stranded on a life raft for 47 days before being rescued by Japanese soldiers. Louie is then taken prisoner and forced to work in a labor camp. He endures harsh conditions and is subjected to torture and abuse. Despite everything he goes through, Louie never gives up hope and remains positive throughout his ordeal. Eventually, he is liberated by American forces and returns home to a hero's welcome. Louie goes on to write a book about his experiences called "Unbroken," which becomes a bestseller.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
Scientists tried for decades to find out why the telomeres stopped shortening during cell division. Soon enough immortal children grew up and became scientists or participants in studies. They maintained the appearance of a child but had the brain of any other. And after several decades more immortal humans were everywhere, but humanity could n't discover how to replicate the genes or mutations causing the phenomena. It's now over one hundred fifty years since the birth of the first immortal. A young looking girl named Esther sat in a grassy field. Trees skirted the field at her back and in front of her sat a city. She'd seen more in her lifetime than any other human ever had. Several wars, booms in technology so astonishing that soon enough scientists said we were going to be making contact with celestial bodies outside of the solar system, and last of all the introduction of a drug you could take that would change every strand of your DNA. The age at which you took it would be the age you appeared to be for the rest of your life. She had a passion for spreading her gift around so others would n't experience the burdens and pains of aging. But the side effects of the drug did n't manifest for years, sometimes decades. Slowly humanity had changed in an unintended way. Random genes were shut off at inappropriate times. Some people lost their ability to experience emotions. Some people lost control of their muscles. No one that took the drug was free of consequences. Only the truly immortal, those born with the mutation, wished to live their lives for all of time. The population of true immortals was still growing and the population of the population of mortals and mortal turned immortals remained about the same. Groups of mortals rose up trying to keep their way of life going, but many wished for them to give up so humanity could be purified of death. Was it cruel to bring a mortal to life in the world of immortals? Immortals ruled the world and they certainly thought so. After the discovery that the drug had severe negative side effects the immortals wished to ban it as well, and so they did. It was illegal to produce it, sell it, possess it, and above all, illegal to have a child after having taken the drug. Esther had left her lab years early. She had given up on finding why they could n't fix the drug or reverse its effects. She moved out to the country, wishing she had never discovered it. The country was an expensive place to live due to the enormous population size humanity had reached, but she had more money than she would ever need. She walked towards a giant tree in the middle of the field. It was one that had been planted when she was young, it gave her comfort to be with something as old as she was. She thought of humanity and what she hoped to see in the next few centuries of her life. She looked down to her right and left. A small headstone stuck up out of the grass on either side. She placed her hands on both of the stones for a moment before closing her eyes to take a nap. "Goodnight Mum, goodnight Dad," she whispered.

Continue the text to compose an original story about 500 words in length:
It was like double-vision, except it was the past. How can something fictional seem so vivid...? The distant, exotic land we came from, its gilded avenues, its glistening intricate spires, its profound natural beauty with lushly verdant banks hugging the rivers that snaked between the dunes. .. None of it was there. It was all nothing more than a dream. But I am not a lie. I stare at my hands, flexing them, examining the callouses accumulated by work never done, cracks formed of age never lived, and despite the warmth of the bright sun just passing its zenith above, I shiver. "Amir," I hear a voice call, and my heart tugs at what I know to be familiarity. "Hassan...?" I uncertainly reply as I look up. Our gazes meet. I could swear I saw in his eyes the same false memories flashing behind mine. Childhood among parents who never lived, in a community that was never built, attending an academy that was never founded, graduating from a ceremony never held... He nods hollowly, as if to confirm these very musings. "... We have to pack the supplies, Amir. His Majesty will be staying at the palace, and the staff are directing us to where we are to stow his wardrobe and leave his tributes to The Sultan." My mouth was dry, but not in response to his words. At some point I realized my'old friend' Hassan was talking only to fill the screaming void in our minds. To'Sound Normal', like'Real People'. My stomach is a knot of ice. Still, the skills of a life as-yet unlived surface readily to the forefront of my mind. How to port the many caskets of His Majesty Prince Ali's wares. "... Yes. I will coordinate with the provisioner. If my memory serves," I pause a bit too long, lost in the jarring disjunction of citing false memories, "... it is customary to serve a great feast with the arrival of a dignitary. The many delicacies of our homeland are sure to leave a resounding impression upon The Sultan's court." Hassan's expression tightens. I feel his heartache, for this homeland which we have never seen with real eyes, and never shall. He hesitantly takes a step nearer and dispenses a conciliatory pat to my shoulder. A mutual understanding. We were truly all feeling it, every last member of His Majesty Prince Ali's vanguard.... he was n't even really a prince. I shudder and turn, to address the court provisioner by name. He's just as haunted and startled as I that we know one another, but everything is running smoothly. We have no solace from our inner thoughts. We can only push on in the hopes that the minutia will wash away the horror.
